mnemonic: Lying on the <radical>ground</radical> is something that looks just like the ground, the number <kanji>One</kanji>. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.
hint: To remember the meaning of <kanji>One</kanji>, imagine yourself there at the scene of the crime. You grab <kanji>One</kanji> in your arms, trying to prop it up, trying to hear its last words. Instead, it just splatters some blood on your face. "Who did this to you?" you ask. The number One points weakly, and you see number Two running off into an alleyway. He's always been jealous of number One and knows he can be number one now that he's taken the real number one out.

mnemonic: The kanji <kanji>two</kanji> and the radical <radical>two</radical> are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!
hint: More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of One. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!

mnemonic: Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is <radical>nine</radical> and the kanji is <kanji>nine</kanji>, making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.
hint: If you know your radicals well, this kanji will be a breeze!

mnemonic: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is <radical>seven</radical> and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also <kanji>seven</kanji>. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.
hint: Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!

mnemonic: Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant <radical>person</radical> because it's a person walking from the side with their arms down? Well this is a <kanji>person</kanji> too!
hint: Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.

mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>enter</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>enter</kanji> as well.
hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

mnemonic: This isn't exactly the same as the <radical>fins</radical> radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly "modified radical" version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? <kanji>Eight</kanji> fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.
hint: Count the fins out in front of you, all the way from one to eight. It'll help if you actually do this. Now smell each fin, and think "Wow, I have to smell all eight of these?" Yes, you do.

mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are <kanji>power</kanji>.
hint: If you know the radicals, you should be feeling fine... No, you should feel powerful!

mnemonic: This <radical>cross</radical> is the symbol for the number <kanji>ten</kanji>. A good way to remember this is to think about all the religions that have crosses and also important sets of tens.
hint: If you're familiar with Christianity, they have a cross and ten commandments. Cross = ten, you see?

mnemonic: This kanji is made up of the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for "one") and the radical for two. Combine <radical>one</radical> and <radical>two</radical> together and what do you get? <kanji>Three</kanji>!
hint: This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three!

mnemonic: You find a <radical>toe</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>. It's weird, because it's <kanji>above</kanji> the ground, not where toes belong.
hint: Focus your imagination on how body parts should be buried, not above ground like this. Sure, finding a toe is a little strange, but finding a toe above the ground? Downright silly.

mnemonic: There's a <radical>toe</radical> <kanji>below</kanji> <radical>ground</radical>.
hint: So, where is the <radical>toe</radical> now? It's <kanji>below</kanji> ground. Imagine yourself digging it out, and thinking... ugh, why does it have to be <kanji>below</kanji> ground like this? So irritating. Will I be able to sew it back on in time to save it?

mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> radical and the <kanji>mouth</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
hint: If you learned your radicals–which the WaniKani system forces you to do (unless you're cheating)–you'll already know the meaning of the kanji.

mnemonic: The <radical>big</radical> radical and the <kanji>big</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
hint: So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well.

mnemonic: The radical for <radical>woman</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>woman</kanji> are exactly the same.
hint: That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.

mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> radical and the <kanji>mountain</kanji> kanji are the same.
hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you are, then you're studying your kanji as well!

mnemonic: The <radical>river</radical> radical and the <kanji>river</kanji> kanji are the same as each other!
hint: So, if you know the radical you know the kanji as well.

mnemonic:
The <radical>construction</radical> radical and the <kanji>construction</kanji> kanji are the same!

This kanji also means <kanji>industry</kanji>, which is what construction is, if you think about it. It's all part of the construction industry.
hint: Know your radicals and you'll know this kanji's meaning.

mnemonic: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same! The radical is <radical>sword</radical>, but we're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese <kanji>sword</kanji>? That's right, the most common is a <kanji>katana</kanji>, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
hint: This kanji also looks a lot like the kanji <ja>力</ja>. To avoid getting them confused, remember that this one is missing the little nubbin at the top, because 90% of the power comes from the sword to cut your enemies down (which is why the sword kanji is 90% of the power kanji).

mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> radical and the <kanji>dirt</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: As long as you know the radical dirt, you know the kanji dirt.

mnemonic: This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember.
hint: As long as you know the radical <radical>thousand</radical> then you know the kanji <kanji>thousand</kanji> as well!

mnemonic: The <radical>evening</radical> radical and the <kanji>evening</kanji> kanji are the same. If you know the radical you know the meaning of the kanji.
hint: Do what you're meant to do. Study those radicals!

mnemonic: The <radical>child</radical> radical and the <kanji>child</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
hint: So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!

mnemonic: The <radical>small</radical> radical and the <kanji>small</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
hint: Knowing radicals sure is nice, huh?

mnemonic: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both <kanji>street</kanji>.
hint: As long as you know the radical street, you know the kanji street.

mnemonic: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one <radical>barb</radical>, and connects the end of it to the top of another <radical>barb</radical>. When he does this, he knows his work is finally <kanji>finish</kanji>ed.
hint: Make sure you look at this amazing fishing lure too - hold it in your hand, see the two barbs fused together. Think about how strange this lure is. Is this really the best in the world? Will this really finish all other fishing lures?

mnemonic: You're sitting on your <radical>stool</radical> <kanji>again</kanji>!!?
hint: Imagine your super comfy, state-of-the-art stool. You take it everywhere with you, and you're always sitting on it. Again, and again, and <kanji>again</kanji>. You love that stool.

mnemonic: What's something with <radical>nine</radical> sides? Just add a <radical>drop</radical> and you'll have something that's almost a <kanji>circle</kanji>.
hint: It's not quite a <kanji>circle</kanji> though. You just need to add a <radical>drop</radical> of liquid to the edges to smooth it out to become a full circle.

mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> you put <radical>barb</radical>s at the bottom of a <radical>slide</radical> because you're a <kanji>genius</kanji> trying to catch another <kanji>genius</kanji>.
hint: Imagine yourself placing the barbs in front of the slide, thinking about how your genius plan will surely catch another genius.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>Middle</radical> and the kanji <kanji>Middle</kanji> are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise you might find yourself in the middle of a kanji-learning problem.

mnemonic: The <radical>five</radical> radical and the <kanji>five</kanji> kanji are the same.
hint: Know your radicals, friend-o.

mnemonic: Just imagine a beast with a <radical>lid</radical> for a head and <radical>fins</radical> for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number <kanji>six</kanji> is the devil's number.
hint: Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (<kanji>six</kanji>), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.

mnemonic: The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The <radical>lid</radical> is inside the <radical>head</radical> for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of <kanji>yen</kanji> coins, the currency of Japan!
hint: Another thing that will help is to associate the word <kanji>round</kanji> to this kanji, because it has both of these meanings. Both are right, and if you learn one that's better than not learning either, but maybe if you think about how round the coins themselves are inside this person's head, you'll remember this one too.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>heaven</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>heaven</kanji>, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
hint: If you know your radicals well (and you should!) you know the meaning of this kanji well, as well!

mnemonic: The <radical>hand</radical> radical and the <kanji>hand</kanji> kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!
hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. It won't be forever that radicals and kanji overlap so nicely like this!

mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>writing</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>writing</kanji> as well.
hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> radical and <kanji>sun</kanji> kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember <kanji>day</kanji> as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
hint: The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!

mnemonic: The <kanji>moon</kanji> kanji is made up of the <radical>moon</radical> radical.
hint: This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!

mnemonic: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both <radical>tree</radical> and <kanji>tree</kanji> are the same in looks and meaning.
hint: So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?

mnemonic: The <radical>water</radical> radical and the <kanji>water</kanji> kanji are the same.
hint: So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.

mnemonic: The <radical>fire</radical> radical and the <kanji>fire</kanji> kanji are the same as each other.
hint: If you know the radicals then this one is EZPZ.

mnemonic: The <radical>dog</radical> radical and <kanji>dog</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
hint: Soon there will be very few kanji/radical-same combos ... so enjoy it while you can.

mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> radical and the <kanji>king</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Hopefully you're a <kanji>king</kanji> of radicals... because if you are, this kanji was super easy for you!

mnemonic: There are two <radical>mountains</radical> in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the <kanji>exit</kanji> before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.
hint: In your imagination, really feel like your life depends on getting out. The important part is the feeling of "needing to get out of the mountain pass." If you have this feeling, you'll be more likely to remember that this kanji means exit, because that's what you want to do when you see this kanji.

mnemonic: <radical>Narwhal</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>s are on the <kanji>right</kanji> side of their head. In fact, some people didn't think they had mouths at all because they weren't looking from the right. Rookie mistake.
hint: Imagine looking at a narwhal from the front. No mouth. Now look at it from the right. Mouth!

mnemonic: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your <radical>legs</radical> end up inside your <radical>mouth</radical>. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with <kanji>four</kanji> sides.
hint: If you can get to square, you should be able to get to four as well, since squares always have four sides.

mnemonic: <radical>Narwhal</radical>s do <radical>construction</radical> with their <kanji>left</kanji> hands (or flippers, I guess). That's because all narwhals are left-handed!
hint: Picture a bunch of narwhals constructing an underwater ice village. They're all working away with their left hands.

mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>book</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>book</kanji> as well.

Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are <kanji>origin</kanji>, <kanji>real</kanji>, and <kanji>main</kanji>. You can figure this out by thinking about how books mainly have their origins in real life.
hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo! And good luck with all the meanings (sorry sorry sorry).

mnemonic: There is a line on the <radical>ground</radical> so you <radical>stop</radical> and a giant sign pops up that says <kanji>CORRECT</kanji>! You obeyed the rules of the road and did the correct thing.
hint: Imagine walking, staring at the ground until you come across a line that you're supposed to stop at. If you stop, the big "correct" sign appears, chiming a happy tune.

mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> has something in his hand that he's <radical>drop</radical>ping... but it bounces too! He's bouncing a <kanji>ball</kanji>
hint: This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a <kanji>ball</kanji>, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the <kanji>ball</kanji>) over and over again, then laying some hoops like a pro.

mnemonic: The <radical>rice paddy</radical> radical and the <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
hint: Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>white</radical> and the kanji <kanji>white</kanji> are the same.
hint: Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!

mnemonic: The <radical>eye</radical> radical and <kanji>eye</kanji> kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
hint: Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study their radicals.

mnemonic: The <radical>stone</radical> radical and <kanji>stone</kanji> kanji are the same thing!
hint: Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>stand</radical> and the kanji <kanji>stand</kanji> are the same thing, so now you know them both.
hint: If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!

mnemonic: You cut the <radical>leaf</radical> with your <radical>sword</radical> into <kanji>ten thousand</kanji> pieces!
hint: If you can get to ten thousand different pieces, then that means your sword is absolutely perfect. If your sword dulls before you get to ten thousand, you have to throw it away.

mnemonic: If you use a <radical>slide</radical> to <radical>enter</radical> a building, you'll be sliding for a <kanji>long time</kanji>.
hint: Imagine a never-ending slide that goes deep down inside a building. You can't see anything in the dark around you, you just plunge down and slide forever. And forever is a long time, my friend.

mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>now</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>now</kanji> as well.
hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

mnemonic: The <radical>origin</radical> radical and the <kanji>origin</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals!

mnemonic: You have <radical>fins</radical> in <radical>private</radical>. But, you want the world to see them, so you take them <kanji>public</kanji>.
hint: Picture yourself in private, with fins. You wish others could see them. "That's it," you decide. "It's time to show the world. I'm going to make my fins public!"

mnemonic: There's a <radical>person</radical> <kanji>inside</kanji> your <radical>head</radical>.
hint: And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're <kanji>inside</kanji> for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's <kanji>inside</kanji> there, doing evil things.

mnemonic: The <radical>fins</radical> that fell onto my <radical>sword</radical> were sliced into two <kanji>part</kanji>s.
hint: The logic of this story makes a lot of sense - even in the kanji itself the fins are falling onto the sword from above. What happens to things that fall onto swords? They become more than one <kanji>part</kanji>.

mnemonic: If you have <radical>seven</radical> <radical>swords</radical>, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to <kanji>cut</kanji> something.
hint: Take these seven swords and swing them around. <kanji>Cut</kanji> everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.

mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> is <radical>dry</radical> at <kanji>noon</kanji>. The sun is brightest at noon, so it dries the morning dew off the slide, making noon the perfect time to slide.
hint: Picture all the kids out sliding on the slide at noon during their lunch break. It's hot and dry and they're very happy.

mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> is your <kanji>friend</kanji>.
hint: Imagine that narwhal sitting there. It waves its flipper and says "hi friend" to you.

mnemonic: You have a <radical>big</radical> guy here, with an extra <radical>drop</radical> of something below his thigh, hanging down. That's <kanji>fat</kanji> right there. He's so fat he has things of fat hanging off his fat.
hint: Maybe you should touch the <kanji>fat</kanji> below his leg just to see what it is... feel it, and squeeze it. It'll help you to remember that this kanji means "fat."

mnemonic: You have a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. The thing about small slides is that they can only fit a <kanji>few</kanji> people at a time.
hint: Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?) with only a few people on it, trying to move forward. Only a few people are required to create a slide traffic jam, though. :(

mnemonic: If you have a <radical>bow</radical> and a <radical>stick</radical> you need to <kanji>pull</kanji> the two back together to shoot it. If you can't pull it, you won't be shooting anything.
hint: Imagine taking a stick and pulling it back into your bow. Imagine how hard you have to pull. This thing is really strong!

mnemonic: The radical <radical>heart</radical> and the kanji <kanji>heart</kanji> are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!
hint: Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.

mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>door</kanji> are the same!
hint: Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.

mnemonic:
The radical and the kanji for <kanji>direction</kanji> are the same! Huzzah!

There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean <kanji>way</kanji> as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own way. "The way of [your name here]."
hint: The only direction you need to go in is forward, it's always the right way.

mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>cow</kanji> are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.
hint: To distinguish this from the "noon" kanji (<ja>午</ja>), try thinking of the bit poking out of the top of this kanji as the cow's head.

mnemonic: The radical and the kanji for <kanji>father</kanji> are the same.
hint: No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!

mnemonic: <kanji>Fur</kanji> and <radical>fur</radical> are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean <kanji>hair</kanji>, too, though more like furry hair.
hint: Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.

mnemonic: The <radical>stop</radical> radical is the same as the <kanji>stop</kanji> kanji.
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

meaning: Older Brother, Big Brother, Elder Brother
mnemonic: Who's someone who's just a <radical>mouth</radical> with <radical>legs</radical>? That's your know-it-all <kanji>older brother</kanji>, who won't shut up about anything.
hint: To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your older brother as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.

mnemonic: We have the <radical>winter</radical> radical and the <radical>two</radical> radical (though it's sort of slanted). What's two times the winter radical, if radicals are just a part of a kanji? Two times would be enough to create the entire kanji, which is also <kanji>winter</kanji>.
hint: You could also think, "Winter too" instead of "two." Because, this kanji is in fact "<kanji>winter</kanji> too."

mnemonic:
Balance a <radical>spoon</radical> on your pointed <radical>fingers</radical> and it will always point <kanji>north</kanji>. The spoon is like a compass needle and your fingers guide the knowledge your body already has and uses it to point north. That's science, friends!

Notice how the fingers radical is a little different here? That's because you're pointing them really hard.
hint: Imagine taking a spoon and balancing it on your fingers. Now watch the spoon spin spin spin until it stops and ultimately points north.

mnemonic: A <radical>triceratops</radical> is laying out to <radical>dry</radical>. But it's so big, and it's laying on its side, so only <kanji>half</kanji> of it gets dry.
hint: Imagine the triceratops on its side, then imagine it getting up. When it stands up normally, half of its body is soaking wet still. It's a half-n-half triceratops right now.

mnemonic:
The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>old</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>old</kanji> as well.

Note: This "old" does not refer to people. Think of it as "old things" instead.
hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

mnemonic: You have a <radical>private</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> that's a <kanji>machine</kanji>. But you have to keep your machine mouth private because it would scare all the non-machine people around you.
hint: Doesn't this kanji look like a machine mouth? Now wouldn't you want to keep that private from the people you know?

mnemonic: You're known to get the ailment <radical>evening</radical> <radical>toe</radical>, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go <kanji>outside</kanji>.
hint: After imagining your <radical>evening</radical> <radical>toe</radical> overheating, rush <kanji>outside</kanji> to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.

mnemonic: You lift the <radical>lid</radical> off a manhole and there's a <radical>towel</radical> with the name of a <kanji>city</kanji> on it.
hint: Picture this towel with the name of a city on it. Any city you like. Maybe it's your city!

mnemonic: The <radical>canopy</radical> you use in <radical>private</radical> is very <kanji>wide</kanji>.
hint: You want your private canopy to be wide so you can sprawl out under it is as much as you want. No one's going to come in and tell you to close your legs or sit up straight. So it can be as wide as you like!

mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> lets out one <radical>drop</radical>, and then another <radical>drop</radical>. The drops dance together in the air, combine, and when they hit the ground, up sprouts your <kanji>mother</kanji>!
hint: Picture these two drops of the sun morphing before your very eyes until they look exactly like your dear ol' mum. She's bright and shining like the sun, and she's looking down at you, her big drop-eyes full of tears.

mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for <radical>task</radical> first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means <kanji>task</kanji> as well.
hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!

mnemonic: The <radical>arrow</radical> radical and the <kanji>arrow</kanji> kanji are the same. Sort of a "straight" shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?
hint: Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!

mnemonic:
The <radical>world</radical> radical and the <kanji>world</kanji> kanji are the same, but there is another really important meaning you need to know: <kanji>generation</kanji>. 

Think of it this way: the world is just made up of many different generations of people, plants, and animals all getting along together.
hint: It's all these generational differences that make the world go 'round!

mnemonic:
The radical <radical>master</radical> and the kanji <kanji>master</kanji> have the same meanings!

This kanji also means <kanji>main</kanji> because the master is the main person of a dojo or household or business.

The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>alligators</radical>... she's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. She's not a politician.. she's not a queen... She's one of the <kanji>Other</kanji> Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.
hint: Imagine different groups of leaders - they're all dressed nice and normal. Then, off to the side are the leaders who are leaders of bears, cats, alligators, and narwhals... they're the <kanji>other</kanji> ones, no matter how you look at it. They are in their own group, and they are considered "others" because society won't accept them :(

mnemonic:
The <radical>leader</radical> for the <radical>ceremony</radical> can't come so you need a <kanji>substitute</kanji> to <kanji>replace</kanji> them ASAP!

This kanji has another meaning too. The leader can't come to the ceremony because they forgot what <kanji>period</kanji> of time it was. If they think they're in the wrong <kanji>age</kanji>, they won't come because they're trying to lead some monkeys in the ceremony instead.
hint: Picture the leader of the ceremony out back, unsure of what period or age they're in, while the substitute leader walks in and stares at them in shock.

mnemonic: The <radical>beggar</radical> is pointing his <radical>forehead</radical> up at you, his feet trapped in the <radical>ground</radical>. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to <kanji>copy</kanji> him to have your own version of him.
hint: You can imagine the whole story - him walking along, you setting a trap... and then whamo! You catch him. Then, come up with some crazy way / invention you're going to copy him. Are you cloning? Are you just taking his skin? Are you removing his forehead to grab his brain? Up to you - just make sure you make it ridiculous enough to remember.

mnemonic: If someone tries to dig up <radical>private</radical> <radical>dirt</radical> on you, tell them no thanks, that stuff is in the <kanji>past</kanji>. Some things should stay in the past. Not everyone needs to know everything about your life and your past.
hint: Keep your private dirt in the past. It's better for everyone.

mnemonic: There's a <radical>mouth</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of <radical>prison</radical> you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of <kanji>number</kanji>s that you don't understand.
hint: What are these numbers? What do they mean? Think over it for a while, get frustrated, and try to figure it out. You can't, though, so you probably won't ever get inside.

mnemonic: If someone has a <radical>big</radical> <radical>head</radical> you have to try to focus on the <kanji>center</kanji> of it when you talk to them.
hint: You don't want to get caught with your eyes wandering all over their big head. Stare right at the center of their face. Ah geez, their eyes are kinda far away from here. You can really only see their nose...

mnemonic: If you want to <radical>dry</radical> your <radical>horns</radical> you need to lay them <kanji>flat</kanji>. If they aren't flat they'll always be a little damp somewhere and you'll never have a moment's <kanji>peace</kanji>.
hint: Imagine carefully taking off your horns and laying them flat on a paper towel. You have to smooth them out so they're as flat as possible.

mnemonic: Take your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>street</radical> to <kanji>hit</kanji> some people! Street fingers are for curling into a fist. And that street fist wants to do some hitting!
hint: Imagine: it's just you, your fingers, and the wild street. It's hitting time!

mnemonic: Add a <radical>drop</radical> of something magical to <radical>water</radical> and suddenly it turns into big block of <kanji>ice</kanji>, just like that.
hint: Imagine yourself adding that drop. What is it exactly? Something pretty potent, that's for sure. Now go ahead and touch the block of ice... wow, it's really cold — and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the <kanji>ice</kanji>.

mnemonic: There’s a <radical>cross</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical>, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say you <kanji>say humbly</kanji>.
hint: Imagine yourself with a cross in your mouth, saying all kinds of humble things. "Oh no, I'm not that good." "Oh no, my mustache doesn't look that great."

mnemonic: <radical>Slide</radical> down a <radical>branch</radical> and your <kanji>skin</kanji> will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.
hint: Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big, branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body.

mnemonic: The <kanji>plate</kanji> kanji and the <radical>plate</radical> radical are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
hint: If you know your radicals, you know your kanji too.

mnemonic: What do you get if you lend a <radical>spirit</radical> your <radical>umbrella</radical>? <kanji>Thanks</kanji>, of course! Especially if that spirit is Totoro, the spirit of the forest.
hint: It's raining, so you lend Totoro your umbrella. As a thanks, he gives you a present wrapped in bamboo leaves.

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> is next to the <radical>tree</radical>. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, <kanji>rest</kanji>ing.
hint: The best thing to do with a tree is rest under it. Picture the leader resting under the tree with his eyes half closed.

mnemonic: <radical>Slide</radical> some <radical>dirt</radical> on your <radical>legs</radical> so you can feel like you're from a <kanji>previous</kanji> time. Everything from the past is in the dirt. Dead people, dinosaur bones, your mom's secrets in a box from her past life. All these things come back to you as you slide the dirt all over your legs.
hint: Imagine the feeling of dirt on your legs. Now think back to the previous day. The previous year. The previous century.

mnemonic: What is the <radical>evening</radical> <radical>mouth</radical>? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so <kanji>famous</kanji> that everybody knows his <kanji>name</kanji> (“Evening Mouth.”).
hint: Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak. There are thousands of others there, wanting to see the giant floating mouth in the night sky. “Evening Mouth” then says “Everyone, what’s my <kanji>name</kanji>!?” and everyone shouts back “Evening Mouth!” in unison. “Evening Mouth” has certainly gotten really <kanji>famous</kanji>.

mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> <radical>child</radical> stands upon the roof, holding up a single <kanji>letter</kanji>, a single <kanji>character</kanji>, a single <kanji>symbol</kanji> for the world to see.
hint: More people can see this character since the kid is on the roof.

mnemonic: The <radical>cow</radical> part of this kanji is slightly altered, but I think you can see where it is. The <radical>gun</radical> looks just fine, though. Think back to a fake memory you have living on the farm. You have your gun, and you gotta use it on a cow (ruh roh). Once a <kanji>year</kanji> on New Year's, you have to go out and shoot one of the cows. It's only a yearly shooting, though, so at least there's that respite.
hint: You'll have to imagine yourself doing this to remember the meaning of the kanji. Focus on the thought that "okay... it's only once a year... I only have to do this once a <kanji>year</kanji>..."

mnemonic: When the <radical>sun</radical> is over the <radical>cross</radical> it's time to go to church... which is so darn <kanji>early</kanji>. And if you want to get to church early, you need to be <kanji>fast</kanji>, otherwise you'll be too late.
hint: Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says EARLY and FAST on it, flashing in big red letters and alternating.

mnemonic: You're looking for a <radical>treasure</radical>, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of <radical>energy</radical>. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a <kanji>spirit</kanji> ball of <kanji>energy</kanji> like you've never seen.
hint: Try to touch the <kanji>energy</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji>, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.

mnemonic: There is a <radical>leaf</radical> growing out of the <radical>sun</radical>! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a <kanji>hundred</kanji>! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.
hint: Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!

mnemonic: The <radical>bamboo</radical> radical and the <kanji>bamboo</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
hint: Just make sure you know your radicals!

mnemonic: The <radical>thread</radical> radical and <kanji>thread</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
hint: This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.

mnemonic: The <radical>ear</radical> radical and <kanji>ear</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
hint: Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!

mnemonic: The <radical>insect</radical> radical and <kanji>insect</kanji> are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
hint: It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!

mnemonic: Someone’s taking <radical>measurements</radical> of the <radical>trees</radical>… Why is someone taking measurements of trees? These people are planning to take the trees and cut them down to make their <kanji>village</kanji>.
hint: There is a whole group of people out there who are measuring these trees. Imagine them asking each other “do you think this will be a good tree for our village center?” and other people nodding in agreement or disagreement as they measure.

mnemonic: <radical>Rice paddy</radical> <radical>power</radical> comes from a <kanji>man</kanji>. One man, in fact. He's running on a big wheel next to the rice paddy and providing all of the power for the rice to grow and be harvested.
hint: Picture the power this man is generating! Now look at the next rice paddy and you'll see it's on a different power grid with a different man powering it.

mnemonic: When you see both a <radical>rice paddy</radical> and a <radical>street</radical> in the same place, you have the makings of a whole <kanji>town</kanji>!
hint: Think about it, a single farm wouldn't need a whole street. Just paths would do. There is a street next to this rice paddy, so there must be other people, which makes this a <kanji>town</kanji>.

mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical> is planting <radical>flowers</radical> so that one day this place may be full of beautiful <kanji>flower</kanji>s.
hint: It's kind of weird that the flowers radical is only a part of the flower kanji, but you'll make do. Just focus on the fact that the leader is planting all these flowers for a bigger picture thing (that's what leaders do). He wants there to be flowers for future generations as well, because he's a nice dude like that.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>see</radical> and the kanji <kanji>see</kanji> are exactly the same!
hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you do, you'll know a lot of kanji as well, almost magically!

mnemonic: The <radical>shellfish</radical> radical and the <kanji>shellfish</kanji> kanji are the same! It can be just the <kanji>shell</kanji> part too.
hint: Shellfish are shellfish, you know?

mnemonic: The radical for <radical>red</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>red</kanji> are the same thing!
hint: What a lucky ducky - as long as you know your radicals, you'll know this kanji's meaning as well!

mnemonic:
The radical for <radical>foot</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>foot</kanji> are exactly the same.

That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is <kanji>sufficient</kanji>. If you think about it, one foot should be <kanji>sufficient</kanji> enough to walk around with if you hop.
hint: Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>car</radical> and the kanji <kanji>car</kanji> are exactly the same.
hint: Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>not</radical> and the kanji <kanji>not</kanji> are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!
hint: Actually, it does make it easy - the radicals make kanji wayyy easier, no?

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> <radical>samurai</radical> didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by <kanji>doing</kanji>.
hint: Imagine the leader samurai doing things. He's doing more than anyone else, no one can keep up with what he's doing.

mnemonic: You put a <radical>lid</radical> on your <radical>father</radical>. But, he won't taste good alone, so you <kanji>mix</kanji> in some other ingredients. They <kanji>mingle</kanji> inside the pot with him.
hint: This may seem traumatic, but actually your father is surprisingly into it. Imagine him mixed in with all kinds of other things. It's important to note that this kanji is about things being mixed in, not so much about the action of mixing. That's another kanji.

mnemonic: The <radical>meet</radical> radical and the <kanji>meet</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

mnemonic: You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> in the distance. But, it's odd. It's perfectly <radical>pi</radical> shaped (that is, circular). Some kind of piceratops, if you will. The reason they are this shape is because they want to absorb as much <kanji>sunlight</kanji> (or just <kanji>light</kanji> is fine, too) as possible. They evolved to be round so they don't have any corners casting a shadow.
hint: Absorbing sunlight is natural for reptiles, after all. And a round one can absorb even more light. Imagine it sitting in a round spot of sun, enjoying the warmth. What a rare sight you've come across!

mnemonic: There's a <radical>mustache</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical>. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the <kanji>same</kanji> as yours!
hint: Pick up the mustache, hold it up next to your face in front of a mirror. It's unbelievable, but it's the same in every way, down to the last hair.

mnemonic: There's a <radical>mouth</radical> inside a <radical>mouth</radical>. But if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending), you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of <kanji>times</kanji> there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means <kanji>revolve</kanji> too. Think of each "time" a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again another time.
hint: Imagine yourself counting and counting smaller and smaller mouths inside of each other, recording the number of times you can find a mouth inside another mouth. Dig deeper and deeper until it feels ridiculous how small the mouths are getting. Be sure to focus on the counting and the number of times you find one. Now, how many mouths is this times two, because your mouth is like this too.

mnemonic: How many <radical>evenings</radical> are there? There are <kanji>many</kanji>.
hint: If you accidentally think "a lot" or something similar, that's okay too. It's the basic meaning that counts, and all these things are pretty close, though eventually you want to get to the point where you know that this kanji does in fact mean <kanji>many</kanji>.

mnemonic: There's a <radical>triceratops</radical> and a <radical>wolverine</radical>. What are they doing together? You'd think they'd fight, but they took their battle to another venue... they're competing in a game show! One of them answers a question, and the host says, "<kanji>Success</kanji>! You're <kanji>correct</kanji>!"
hint: Feel free to think through several questions and answers, but make sure they're all right, because that's what we're focusing on. Also make sure to focus on the triceratops and the wolverine themselves. You want to make sure that when you see these two radicals you automatically know they're playing in a game show, not doing anything else, like fighting or racing or something.

mnemonic: You see some <radical>windows</radical>... you have a <radical>gun</radical>. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... <kanji>every</kanji> single one of them. <kanji>Each</kanji> and every one.
hint: Make a point to make sure you get <kanji>every</kanji> one, and don't miss any of them. Actually search around in your imagination for any more windows, because you want to stress it's important you hit <kanji>each</kanji> and every window with your gun.

mnemonic: The poor <radical>alligator</radical> was taken far inland by a <radical>tsunami</radical>. Now his only source of water is a tiny <kanji>pond</kanji> that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food.
hint: Imagine the alligator riding the tsunami in. When he hits the ground, and the water recedes, he's all alone in a pond, but it doesn't provide much for him. Imagine him looking for food in the little, shallow pond. Imagine him trying to stay wet... it's just not a great situation to be in, unfortunately.

mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> radical and <kanji>rice</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning. This also refers to "America," maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
hint: Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.

mnemonic: The <radical>feather</radical> radical and <kanji>feather</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
hint: Have you been studying your radicals? If so, this'll be easy!

mnemonic: In a <radical>coffin</radical> is someone <radical>begging</radical>. But, it won't work. You won't listen. So, the man in the coffin just begins to <kanji>think</kanji>: What could I have done better in my life? Why am I in this situation? How will I get out? Think, damnit, think!!
hint: Imagine him changing from a begging position to a stereotypical "thinking" position, hand on chin, eyebrows furrowed. Focus on the beggar's thinking. This is a pretty abstract idea to imagine, so it will be important to create a very vivid picture in your mind's eye.

mnemonic: The <radical>meat</radical> radical and <kanji>meat</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
hint: Study those radicals, and perhaps we'll eat some meat tonight.

mnemonic: The <radical>self</radical> radical and <kanji>self</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
hint: Radicals have self. Kanji has self. Kanji and radicals can sometimes be the same thing... so do they really have "self"? Only way to find out is to study both of them hard!

mnemonic: The <radical>color</radical> radical and <kanji>color</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
hint: Color me pink! This kanji's super easy if you know your radicals.

mnemonic: The <radical>go</radical> radical and the <kanji>go</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
hint: If you know your radicals well enough (and you do), you'll know this kanji.

mnemonic: The <radical>west</radical> radical and the <kanji>west</kanji> kanji are the same. Isn't that nice?
hint: Make sure you know all those radicals, will make your life more pleasant.

mnemonic: Our <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>lip ring</radical>. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? <kanji>WHAT</kanji>??
hint: Think of our president (or your prime minister, or dictator, or whatever) and imagine this person appearing on television one morning with a big ol' lip ring. Feel surprised by it. Just say "What??" over and over again. You want to have the feeling of "what" in you when you imagine this - that'll help you to remember this kanji's meaning.

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> has a <radical>book</radical> all about the human <kanji>body</kanji>. Knowing about bodies is a privilege. One that only leaders get—it helps them control all their subjects, like you.
hint: Imagine looking down at your body and thinking, huh, I wonder what all that junk is? Oh well, I'm sure the leader has it all figured out in that book of hers.

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>key</radical> is the key that <kanji>make</kanji>s all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
hint: Imagine the leader taking his key to open up a safe that has a button to make other keys for the underlings. No key is as great as this key, though.

mnemonic: The <radical>treasure</radical>s are in the <radical>mouth</radical> where there’s <radical>ice</radical>. How cryptic! You want to find the treasure, that’s for sure (treasure is great!). It is somewhere where there is ice, so maybe the arctic? What you are looking at is a <kanji>diagram</kanji> which will guide you there.
hint: Imagine looking at a diagram or map – and it has pictures of treasure in an area where ice is. This is where you will find the mystical treasure. This diagram will show the way. You're so excited that you found this map!

mnemonic: You have a <radical>samurai</radical> with a <radical>flag</radical> on a <radical>stick</radical>. On his flag is this symbol, the kanji for <kanji>voice</kanji>. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word "voice" written on it to protest.
hint: Imagine him and other samurai with their flags on sticks waving them around shouting things like "we want a voice in politics!" etc., etc.

mnemonic: There’s a <radical>samurai</radical> with (just) his <radical>forehead</radical> and <radical>legs</radical>. Everything in between is missing. What happened to everything in between? He was low on money, so he had to <kanji>sell</kanji> it all, leaving him with only the top and the bottom.
hint: Imagine this terrifying samurai. You have legs… okay, that’s normal. But, then you have just a giant forehead on the top of everything else, walking around. It's pretty scary that someone would sell such important parts of their body.

mnemonic: There is someone with a <radical>bow</radical> and a <radical>stick</radical>, wearing <radical>horns</radical>, going down a <radical>slide</radical>. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your <kanji>younger brother</kanji>.
hint: Just pretend you have a younger brother for now, even if you don't. Also be sure to imagine this person really vividly. He is a stereotypical little boy, playing dress up with horns and a bow and stick (he can't have an arrow, that's dangerous), and he's going down a slide too.

mnemonic: You're walking at night when you discover a <radical>lantern</radical> covered entirely in <radical>hair</radical>, making it a very strange <kanji>shape</kanji>. In fact, this is a <kanji>form</kanji> you'd never expect a lantern to take.
hint: Picture all the different shapes this hairy lantern could take in your mind.

mnemonic: There's <radical>rice</radical> spread out all over the <radical>ground</radical>. This will cause the Predator to <kanji>come</kanji> because he loves kome (rice). Then once he's gone, the <kanji>next</kanji> Predator will come to eat.
hint: Also imagine everyone else coming to the rice next. When rice spills, people come from all around to line up and grab a handful of it to take home. Who's next? Come forward!

mnemonic: Plant a <radical>spirit</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> before you start your <kanji>company</kanji> and it will be successful. That's what all the great, old Japanese companies did back in the olden days. That's why companies like Mitsubishi have been around for hundreds of years. They planted a spirit in the dirt to help their company grow, and grow it did!
hint: Picture a young person way back in old-timey history times burying the spirit of one of their ancestors in the dirt. Now watch as an old-timey time lapse plays out in front of your eyes and a company is born!

mnemonic: Your <radical>task</radical> in <radical>prison</radical> is to bend things into different <kanji>angle</kanji>s and then put them in the <kanji>corner</kanji>. No one will tell you why you're doing this, but you get a couple cents an hour to do it, so you aren't going to complain.
hint: Picture yourself sitting in a corner, bending pieces of metal and scrap to fit the angle of that corner.

mnemonic: The <radical>say</radical> radical and the <kanji>say</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

mnemonic: There's a <radical>hat</radical> decorated with <radical>fins</radical> and (presumably fish) <radical>mouth</radical>s on it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the <kanji>valley</kanji> people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the "Valley Girls" of California, Hollywood / LA. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed "cool" or something like that.
hint: Imagine a bunch of Valley Girls walking around with these strange hats. Fins and fish mouths... what a strange new fad.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>run</radical> and the kanji <kanji>run</kanji> are exactly the same!
hint: Make sure you know your radicals!

mnemonic: Someone on a <radical>scooter</radical> has an <radical>axe</radical>, and they're getting <kanji>near</kanji> to you really fast! Oh no, they're so <kanji>close</kanji> now, you need to get out of here!
hint: Picture a scooter coming toward you in the dark. You see the gleam of the axe as it looms nearer and nearer.

mnemonic: The <radical>village</radical> you always think of first is your <kanji>hometown</kanji>.
hint: Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.

mnemonic: The <radical>life</radical> radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the <radical>winter</radical> radical, you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the <kanji>wheat</kanji> you store away.
hint: Imagine you're starving. It's cold and you've run out of food. You don't know what you're going to do. If you don't find something, you'll lose your life. Then, you break open a barrel, and wheat pours out. It's beautiful. You just found some life in the middle of winter.

mnemonic: You have a wild <radical>viking</radical> <radical>child</radical> you have to take care of. He won't do anything but <kanji>study</kanji>, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
hint: Of course, this isn't what you'd expect of a little viking child. It's the opposite. That's why it's so surprising! He loves to study!

mnemonic: You have a <radical>tree</radical> and another <radical>tree</radical>. You basically have yourself a <kanji>forest</kanji>!
hint: Follow the logic of this one and you should be okay.

mnemonic: Giving a <radical>roof</radical> <radical>legs</radical> is the kind of <radical>construction</radical> you do. You make it so a roof can be in the <kanji>sky</kanji>. In addition to meaning "sky", this kanji often means <kanji>empty</kanji>. Think about it - there's nothing more empty than the sky!
hint: Think about it. If you give a roof legs, it goes even higher up. What's higher up? The sky is!

mnemonic: The <radical>gold</radical> radical and the <kanji>gold</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Just know your radicals and you'll be golden, so to speak.

mnemonic: The radical for <radical>rain</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>rain</kanji> are the same thing.
hint: Make sure you know your radicals!

mnemonic: The <radical>blue</radical> radical and the <kanji>blue</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
hint: Don't feel blue, you should know this kanji automagically!

mnemonic: You plant your <radical>flowers</radical> in the light of the <radical>sun</radical> in the shape of a <radical>cross</radical>, but it's too hot—the sun is too strong—and you end up with <kanji>grass</kanji>. Flowers can't grow in these conditions.
hint: Think of how disappointed you are. You wanted a beautiful cross of flowers, and now you just have a big overgrown patch of thick grass. It isn't even pretty green grass, it's a little brown and damaged from the sun.

mnemonic: For some reason, you are <radical>stand</radical>ing on the <radical>sun</radical>. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the <kanji>sound</kanji> of you burning up.
hint: Imagine a super loud sizzling sound, drowning everything else out. It's ridiculously loud, and hurts your ears more than the sun's heat hurts your skin.

mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical> is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great <kanji>change</kanji> in the world.
hint: Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally <kanji>change</kanji> everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can do with such a blunt, small, device!

mnemonic:
A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>alligator</radical> lives in the <kanji>earth</kanji>, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.

You can think of this word as <kanji>ground</kanji> too, because that's kind of what earth is made of.
hint: Imagine seeing the earth moving as a dirt alligator rises out from the ground. You should run.

mnemonic: Under the <radical>ground</radical>, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found <kanji>both</kanji> a <radical>mountain</radical> and a <radical>head</radical>, two strange things to find underground.
hint: You'll want to focus on the part where you find <kanji>both</kanji>, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so well finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.

mnemonic: <radical>Kings</radical> with <radical>hats</radical>. Did you know that <kanji>all</kanji> kings wear hats?
hint: Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what, every single one of them (aka <kanji>all</kanji> of them) wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, and normal hats. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they all are wearing them.

mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> hits your <radical>mustache</radical>. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from <kanji>yonder</kanji>," you say, <kanji>facing</kanji> that way.
hint: Yonder is a bit of a weird word, but it fits the meaning of this kanji quite well. You'll have to trust me that it's more useful in Japanese than it is in English. When you imagine through this mnemonic, make sure the drop comes from the side and hits you in the mustache with quite a bit of force. That means it came from a far distance thus making you look over "yonder."

mnemonic: With a <radical>roof</radical> over her head, a <radical>woman</radical> can <kanji>relax</kanji>. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a safe place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super <kanji>cheap</kanji>, so she can even relax about her finances.
hint: Picture the super relaxed woman lounging under her cheap but sturdy roof. Ah, she doesn't have a care in the world!

mnemonic: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s in the large <radical>river</radical> that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's <kanji>states</kanji> or <kanji>province</kanji>s.
hint: Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!

mnemonic: <radical>Twenty</radical> <radical>mouths</radical> are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful <kanji>music</kanji> together.
hint: Listen to the twenty mouths. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Also note that this kanji also means "bend." Imagine the music coming out at you <kanji>bend</kanji>ing all around in strange shapes through the air.

mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> is all you <kanji>have</kanji>. Imagine one of each under your arms.
hint: You don't have anything else. This is it. All you have.

mnemonic: You <radical>lack</radical> <radical>ice</radical>. So you go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the <kanji>next</kanji> store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!
hint: Feel a little frustrated you can't find ice. Have the words "<kanji>next</kanji> next next" echoing through your head as you go from store to store, irritated.

mnemonic: If the <radical>yakuza</radical> hands you a <radical>spoon</radical>, <kanji>death</kanji> is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.
hint: This spoon isn't for pudding, it's for death!

mnemonic: The <radical>sheep</radical> radical and the <kanji>sheep</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.
hint: You are no sheep—you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!

mnemonic: The <radical>blood</radical> radical and <kanji>blood</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
hint: There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!

mnemonic: There is a <radical>lid</radical> covering all the <radical>mouth</radical>s that are too <radical>small</radical> to feed themselves, forming the <kanji>capital</kanji>. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other.
hint: Picture the capital of your country. How many mouths have come together to support each other there? A thousand? A million? More?!

mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>king</radical> extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his <kanji>country</kanji>, give or take a few <radical>drop</radical>s.
hint: Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.

mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> is wearing a <radical>lid</radical> and is standing outside in <radical>winter</radical>. Plus it's raining and she's covered in <radical>drop</radical>s of water. On top of all this, it's <kanji>night</kanji>.
hint: If it helps, you can come up with a reason why she's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is she wearing a lid on her head? Probably because she's protecting her people from something that comes at night.

mnemonic: Who's that <radical>woman</radical> pretending to be a <radical>jet</radical>? That's my <kanji>younger sister</kanji>. *Sigh*
hint: Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!

meaning: Older Sister, Big Sister, Elder Sister
mnemonic: The only <radical>woman</radical> in this <radical>city</radical> is your <kanji>older sister</kanji>. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.
hint: You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.

mnemonic: A long time ago, someone put up a <radical>canopy</radical> over their <radical>fortune</radical> telling booth and created the first <kanji>shop</kanji>. This <kanji>store</kanji> was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!
hint: Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.

mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> AND the <radical>moon</radical> are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly <kanji>bright</kanji> outside.
hint: Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.

mnemonic: Behind that <radical>tree</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> is rising in the <kanji>east</kanji>. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.
hint: Picture the sun behind the tree, don't picture the sun alone, you'll burn your eyes. It's slowly coming up behind it. Now think: where does the sun rise? In the east!

mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> at a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were <kanji>walk</kanji>ing.
hint: Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."

mnemonic: There's a close-up of a <radical>leaf</radical> in a <radical>rice paddy</radical> inside of a <radical>box</radical>. Wait, it's not a box, this whole thing is just a <kanji>drawing</kanji>.
hint: Look closely at this box-shaped drawing. See each little stroke, smell the paper and the lead.

mnemonic: You accidentally stab your <radical>cross</radical> into the <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>lion</radical>. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to <kanji>fix</kanji> it right now. I'll be <kanji>direct</kanji> with you, this is something you have to fix on your own.
hint: How will you fix this mistake though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything.

mnemonic: Just before saying something important, you take an <radical>arrow</radical> to the <radical>mouth</radical> which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you <kanji>know</kanji> with someone else.
hint: Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).

mnemonic:
The <radical>long</radical> radical and the <kanji>long</kanji> kanji are the same! 

This kanji also means <kanji>leader</kanji>, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know?
hint: As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.

mnemonic:
There are some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>knife</radical> in <kanji>front</kanji> of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.

This kanji means <kanji>before</kanji> too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all.
hint: Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.

mnemonic: The <radical>cross</radical> you're holding above your <radical>head</radical> to keep your <radical>horns</radical> <radical>dry</radical> keeps pulling you <kanji>south</kanji>. Probably because it's warmer in the south of Japan, so it's easier to keep things dry.
hint: Look down and see the compass pointing south and feel the cross pulling you in that direction.

mnemonic: On the <radical>dirt</radical> you've made a <radical>roof</radical> over the <radical>ground</radical> where you can be in <radical>private</radical>. This is your <kanji>room</kanji>! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.
hint: Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof and the dirt on the ground. It's your own little private place.

mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around to <radical>poop</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> you never know what could be happening <kanji>behind</kanji> you. <kanji>After</kanji> you're done you could turn <kanji>back</kanji> to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.
hint: Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.

mnemonic: In a <radical>rice paddy</radical> you find a <radical>heart</radical> and it makes you <kanji>think</kanji>. You think a lot of <kanji>thought</kanji>s like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"
hint: Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.

mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> that gives <radical>life</radical> is our very own <kanji>star</kanji> (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
hint: Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> of <radical>tongue</radical>s is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... <kanji>lively</kanji>!
hint: Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you point your <radical>gun</radical> out the <radical>window</radical> at it. "You better turn back, <kanji>sea</kanji>, or I'll shoot!"
hint: You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.

mnemonic: Your <radical>fortune</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s down to a single <kanji>point</kanji> in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go.
hint: Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.

mnemonic: You scoop some <radical>grain</radical>s into a <radical>ladle</radical> to do <kanji>science</kanji>. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science <kanji>course</kanji>.
hint: Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!

mnemonic: You come across an <radical>angel</radical> wearing a <radical>hat</radical> that's covered in <radical>flowers</radical>. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make <kanji>tea</kanji> out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.
hint: How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*

mnemonic: The radical for <radical>eat</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>eat</kanji> are the same! Lucky you.
hint: If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is <kanji>meal</kanji>. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>neck</radical> and the kanji <kanji>neck</kanji> are exactly the same!
This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. <radical>Lack</radical> becomes <kanji>Lack</kanji>!
hint: If you know the radical you know this.

mnemonic: Your <radical>clan</radical> is where you get your name. But not your given name, your <kanji>family name</kanji>. That's why people have names that mean "in a rice paddy" and "near the ferry crossing." The location of your clan determined your <kanji>surname</kanji>! Hope your ancestors didn't live on "Poo Lake" or something.
hint: Think about your own surname in your language. Where did it come from? Were you a clan of village dwellers? Maybe you made shoes! You should look it up and find out!

mnemonic: A giant <radical>cross</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> stands above you. "I am <kanji>reason</kanji>!" it says to you. It is the Cross of Reason.
hint: Because it's a cross with a mouth, it thinks that it is reason in all the chaos.

mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>umbrella</radical>, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar <kanji>bills</kanji> floating down.
hint: The sick part of this is that those dollar <kanji>bills</kanji> were once this tree's friends. The tree is sobbing uncontrollably as pieces of his friends fall on him and all around him - which is why he's using the umbrella to protect himself.

mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>clan</radical> are a group of <kanji>people</kanji>. They are the <kanji>people</kanji> of a <kanji>nation</kanji>.
hint: The mouth clan are distinct peoples. They do, of course, use their mouths.

mnemonic: While riding your <radical>scooter</radical>, you take your <radical>sword</radical> and cut out an <kanji>area</kanji> on the ground. This whole place is your area now!
hint: Imagine riding your scooter around in a really large circle, pressing your sword into the ground as you do. Once you close the circle, you claim to everyone around that this is YOUR area, and they aren't allowed in.

mnemonic: You have to take the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring that leader's height and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you <kanji>attach</kanji> another head to the top of the leader's head.
hint: Make sure you really feel like the person can’t be a leader because they’re too short when you measure them (I know this isn’t true, but we’re remembering kanji here, anything goes!). As long as you feel disconcerted that the leader isn’t tall enough, you should be able to remember that you need to attach something to the leader to make them tall enough. The fact that you’re attaching another head to the top of the leader's head is pretty weird too, and should help you to remember the meaning.

meaning: From, Since, Compared With, With, By Means Of
mnemonic: The <radical>lion</radical> drops a <radical>drop</radical> of saliva onto this <radical>person</radical> <kanji>from</kanji> above. The person is in a much worse place <kanji>compared with</kanji> where they were before, <kanji>since</kanji> they only just recently fell into this pit.
hint: Picture the person, the lion is leaning over them, the drop of spit dangling from their mouth. "I-I want to go back where I came from," the person gasps, shaking.

mnemonic: That <radical>slide</radical> is your <radical>husband</radical>'s only <kanji>fault</kanji>. He loves that slide, more than you, and it's the only thing you don't like about him.
hint: Imagine looking out the window of your house and watching your husband slide down his slide over and over. He's not even good at it, he falls off the side halfway down most of the time. You want to complain, but he's pretty decent otherwise. This is his only fault.

mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> coming out of the patient's <radical>heart</radical> is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for <kanji>certain</kanji> death.
hint: As you imagine the mad scientist drawing blood out of the patient's heart with a small slide, also imagine a little meter hooked up to him as well. On one end is "SURVIVE!" on the other end is "CERTAIN DEATH." Right now the finger is pointing close to <kanji>certain</kanji> death, though :(

mnemonic: You're flying in a <radical>jet</radical>. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, "Are we there yet? Are we there yet?" You have to keep responding. "<kanji>Not yet</kanji>! Not yet! NOT YET!"
hint: Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!

mnemonic: This kanji uses a modified <radical>jet</radical> radical. The front area of the wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the <kanji>end</kanji> of the earth.
