mnemonic: You find some <radical>fingers</radical> from <radical>long ago</radical>. They must have been <kanji>set aside</kanji> by their previous owners. They definitely weren't cut off or anything, someone just decided they didn't want them anymore and set them aside.
hint: What would have to happen for you to set aside your own fingers? Try to imagine it right now.

mnemonic: Wipe your <radical>fingers</radical> on this <radical>table</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> to see what it was <kanji>based on</kanji>. The cold winter weathers cover the table in frost, and when you wipe it away, you can see traces of what the table was originally based on. All tables have to be based on something, even if it's just other tables that came before them.
hint: Imagine tracing your fingers over the table, the cold winter frost stinging them, as you reveal the secrets of this table and what it was based on.

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>righteousness</radical> is the only one who can run this <kanji>ceremony</kanji>. Why? Because it's a very pure ceremony, and only those with an extremely righteous mind can run it.
hint: Have him run your ceremony for you. Think about why he is so righteous, then think about an extremely righteous ceremony.

mnemonic: Each <radical>tree</radical> needs its <radical>drum</radical> <radical>measurement</radical> done before you can say it's really made of <kanji>wood</kanji>.
hint: There are a lot of hoodlums out there that try to dress as trees and confuse people. So make sure you measure their drum before you cut one down or tell someone your secrets under it.

mnemonic: In the <radical>trash</radical> is a weird looking <radical>fruit</radical>. Someone decided to <kanji>abandon</kanji> it here.
hint: Most people abandon fruit when it's misshapen. It's probably fine though...

mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> has <radical>legs</radical> that belong to a <kanji>tiger</kanji>. You know, a tiger has the legs of a tiger. This is common knowledge. Nothing new here.
hint: Look at the tiger running with his tiger legs. So majestic. So fierce.

mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> <radical>insect</radical> is a <kanji>firefly</kanji>. In the insect kingdom, the insect most resembling a Viking is undoubtedly the firefly.
hint: Imagine this little firefly blinking his firefly light as he flies around shouting a Viking warcry and brandishing an axe. Yaaaargh!

mnemonic: On the <radical>insect</radical> <radical>signpost</radical> there is a single sign that says <kanji>bee</kanji>.
hint: This particular insect signpost points you to where the bee is.

mnemonic: The <radical>alcohol</radical> you take a <radical>measurement</radical> most carefully of is <kanji>sake</kanji>. Sake is very important to the alcohol culture in Japan, so you must make sure to measure it out to the precise amount.
hint: Imagine this sake as you measure it out. Hear it pouring out of the bottle as you catch the whiff of sweet alcohol in the air.

mnemonic: The <radical>roof</radical> (hive) on a <radical>certain</radical> <radical>insect</radical> (a bee) is what protects all of the <kanji>honey</kanji>.
hint: Bees are a certain insect that build a roof around their honey.

mnemonic: You're digging in the <radical>dirt</radical> when you find a <radical>tiger</radical> and a <radical>cactus</radical>. You keep digging until you realize that these are a part of some big <kanji>ruins</kanji>. They're the ruins of tiger and cactus statues. It looks like whoever used to live here worshiped tigers and cacti. Or maybe they ate them. But now their whole civilization is just ruins.
hint: Imagine looking through these ruins. Picture the broken tiger and cactus statues. Try to imagine the people who used to live here before it turned to ruins.

mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> that <radical>oversee</radical>s other boats, land, and people is usually a <kanji>warship</kanji>. They're the big boats that oversee everything around them. And if anyone steps out of line, a warship can take care of it.
hint: Picture a huge warship overseeing everything around it. It's big and kinda scary.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> carries a <radical>husband</radical> and his <radical>husband</radical> up into the <radical>sun</radical> where they <kanji>conceal</kanji> their centaur. The two husbands run a centaur farm, but the local government isn’t too pleased by this so they have to conceal their centaurs in the sun unless they want them to be confiscated by the government.
hint: Imagine the tsunami carrying the husbands and the centaur up into the sun. Hear the water gushing as they conceal the centaur up there. That tsunami is gigantic.

mnemonic: A <radical>gladiator</radical> turns his <radical>hand</radical> into a <kanji>fist</kanji>. A fist for punching other gladiators.
hint: Picture the gladiator squeezing his hand into a tight fist, raising it up and yelling.

mnemonic: You climb up a <radical>mountain</radical> and a <radical>cliff</radical> in search of <radical>fire</radical>, but all you find is <kanji>charcoal</kanji>. You can make fire with the charcoal, but you were hoping to find fire itself. All that climbing for nothing.
hint: You’re angry that you could only find charcoal so you take the charcoal in your hands and you crush it atop the cliff on the mountain. Feel the charcoal breaking in your hands as the wind carries the charcoal dust off from the top of the cliff on the mountain.

mnemonic: A <radical>fire</radical> in the <radical>rice paddy</radical> burns down the <kanji>field</kanji>. The rice paddy fire spreads out from the paddy and consumes the field next to it. This rice paddy fire has ravaged your entire farm!
hint: Look at this fire burning the rice paddy and the surrounding field. Smell burnt rice in the air as you see the flames dance before your eyes.

mnemonic: The <radical>wrap</radical> radical and the <kanji>wrap</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

mnemonic: The <radical>clothes</radical> radical and the <kanji>clothes</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!

This <radical>leader</radical> has <radical>two</radical> things that remind him of his <kanji>humanity</kanji>: his shoes, and his hat. These two things remind the leader of his humanity because humans are the only ones who wear shoes and hats.
hint: Reflect upon your own humanity. What does it mean to be human? Is it wearing shoes and hats? Probably.

mnemonic: Aside from <radical>gold</radical> there are a <radical>wide</radical> variety of other <kanji>mineral</kanji>s as well.
hint: Think of the wide range of minerals there are that aren't gold. There are a lot.

mnemonic: Dig up a <radical>mole</radical> and you <kanji>attain</kanji> a mole status. You're always trying to attain a new level for yourself and now you get to be on the mole level!
hint: It's actually pretty easy to attain mole status. Just stand in a field. Wait for the ground to move under you and shove your hand in the earth. Blam! An achievement pops up above your head and you're there.

mnemonic: Something you <radical>say</radical> to someone you <radical>become</radical> attached to should be said with <kanji>sincerity</kanji>. You need to speak with sincerity when you say things to someone who will eventually become your significant other, for example.
hint: Imagine saying something with sincerity to someone you want to become important to you. Say something like, “I love you” out loud. Say it with the utmost sincerity.

mnemonic: Everyone has a <radical>poop</radical> <radical>guy</radical> from their <kanji>hometown</kanji>. You know. That poop guy. And every single time you try to visit your hometown, poop guy is there making everyone uncomfortable and reminding you why you left in the first place.
hint: Picture the poop guy from your hometown. Picture him really vividly. The awkward, rude things he does. The way he smells. The way he makes you never want to come back.

mnemonic: There is a tiny <radical>leader</radical> on <radical>Wolverine</radical>’s <radical>forehead</radical> sitting on a <radical>stool</radical> and commanding his troops to <kanji>invade</kanji> Wolverine’s brain. These tiny soldiers are going to invade Wolverine’s body in an attempt to destroy him. The leader himself isn’t going to invade Wolverine’s brain, he’s just going to sit on the stool and supervise.
hint: Imagine the little leader sitting on Wolverine’s forehead as he shouts “Invade! Invade invade! Invade his brain and destroy the Wolverine!”

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> gets a nice uniform for the <radical>sake</radical> of not wanting to look like a <kanji>fake</kanji>. The leader is a fake, he just doesn’t want to look like one. He’s not really a leader, but he thinks he should get an official-looking uniform for the sake of not looking like a fake.
hint: Look at this fake leader. See him scramble into a uniform. Does he look like a real leader? Or can you tell that he is a fake?

mnemonic: Even though you’ve <radical>old</radical> <radical>legs</radical>, you <kanji>overcome</kanji> your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!
hint: Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.

mnemonic: The <radical>mole</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> ready for your <kanji>arrival</kanji>. You get out of your airplane, you step on the ground and... ouch! You stepped right on the knife, and there's the mole, sticking it out of the ground. "I checked the schedule for your arrival!" it squeaks happily, and disappears.
hint: Welp, your arrival didn't go smoothly. You have a knife in your foot. I'm not sure what you did to make that mole hate you, but you'll have to be more careful next time.

mnemonic: If you have one <radical>stool</radical> and another <radical>stool</radical>, you have a <kanji>pair</kanji> of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.
hint: Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process.

mnemonic: Put an <radical>axe</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> to express your <kanji>philosophy</kanji>. Your philosophy of putting weapons in your mouth. Everyone else seems to think it's a stupid philosophy, so you're showing them that it's not with actions!
hint: Imagine expressing your philosophy, your deepest thoughts and beliefs, by putting it in your mouth.

mnemonic: Under the <radical>cross</radical> is a <radical>mouth</radical> and another <radical>mouth</radical> wearing special <radical>clothes</radical> because they're in <kanji>mourning</kanji>.
hint: Picture the cross looming overhead, people's mouths open so they can sob loudly, and everyone wearing the same color clothes (just picture whatever color works for your particular culture/religion combo).

mnemonic: A <radical>servant</radical> secures a <radical>stool</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> so that it is a <kanji>solid</kanji> sitting device. If you just throw a stool on the ground it will flop over easily. But if you have a servant to dig it into the dirt a bit, it becomes nice and solid and safe for sitting!
hint: Picture two stools in your mind. One is solid, you want to sit on it. The other looks like the wind will knock it over. Don't sit on that!

mnemonic: Under the <radical>canopy</radical>, you use a <radical>tree</radical> for your <kanji>floor</kanji>. It also becomes your <kanji>bed</kanji>, because hey, what is a floor but the original bed?
hint: You lay it down, cut it into slats, and voila! A floor! And a bed!

mnemonic: Someone's <radical>fingers</radical> touch your <radical>tongue</radical> and <kanji>fasten</kanji> it together. You can't talk. All you can do is make sad tongue-less sounds as you try to figure out who would fasten your tongue like this.
hint: Try to fasten your own tongue with your fingers right now. You probably can't do it, right? That's because your fingers are too big and your tongue is too slippery.

mnemonic: Shoot a <radical>melon</radical> out of a <radical>bow</radical> and it will fly in a steep <kanji>arc</kanji>. Melons are too heavy to fly straight, after all.
hint: Imagine shooting a really heavy melon out of a bow. Watch it make an arc through the air. Trace the arc with your finger.

mnemonic: When your <radical>finger</radical>s move like that, you know it's an <radical>omen</radical> of a <kanji>challenge</kanji> that will face you soon in the future.
hint: What kind of challenge is it? If you look closely at your fingers sometimes you can figure out the challenge that is to come based on their movements.

mnemonic: You see a <radical>flag</radical> near the <radical>exit</radical>, so you use your <radical>fingers</radical> to <kanji>dig</kanji> there. Most flags mark something, and this exit is pretty obvious, so there must be something under here. At least that's what you think to yourself as you dig.
hint: Imagine digging under the flag by the exit of your building with your bare fingers. The dirt is getting under your fingernails as you dig. It's getting on your knees. It's everywhere.

mnemonic: If you have <radical>fingers</radical> it's <radical>easy</radical> to <kanji>hoist</kanji> things above your head. If you don't have fingers, well, it's not so easy.
hint: Hoist the sails! Hoist the anchor! Hoist a baby! All of these situations are easier if you have a ton of working fingers. (The more the better.)

mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> in a <radical>shop</radical> to <kanji>grip</kanji> what you want to buy.
hint: Imagine picking up a few different things in a shop. If something fits nicely in your grip: buy it. If it's too small or too big, put it back.

mnemonic: You grab a <radical>satellite</radical> with your <radical>fingers</radical> and <kanji>shake</kanji> it! You're an astronaut and it's your job. Don't worry, the satellite won't break or anything, it's strong for space travel. Just do as you're told and shake the sucker.
hint: Imagine being in space and shaking a satellite with your fingers.

mnemonic: Use <radical>simultaneous</radical> <radical>jackhammer</radical>s to perform the <kanji>purification</kanji> ritual. Two jackhammers running perfectly in sync will purify your body, mind, and soul! (And the ground around you that's being jackhammered.)
hint: Close your eyes and feel the purification begin. Try not to let the loud jackhammering sound bother you, just focus on the simultaneous vibrations cleansing you inside and out.

mnemonic: To your <radical>car</radical> you take an <radical>axe</radical>. The <radical>sun</radical> has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just like that <kanji>temporarily</kanji>. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.
hint: Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun messed it up temporarily.

mnemonic: You hit a <radical>tree</radical> with an <radical>axe</radical> so you can do some <kanji>analysis</kanji> on it. To do the analysis on the tree, a cross section needs to be obtained, so you must chop it in half with your axe.
hint: Imagine taking this axe in your hands and chopping away at this tree to do your analysis. Hear the chop chop chop as wood chips fly into your face.

mnemonic: In the <radical>tree</radical> <radical>district</radical> of town you can buy a lot of tree products, including doors. With those doors, though, you always need <kanji>hinge</kanji>s.
hint: Don't forget to buy a hinge. Your door purchase will <kanji>hinge</kanji> on your hinges.

mnemonic: For a <radical>car</radical>, the <radical>reason</radical> why it works is because its wheels spin on their <kanji>axis</kanji>. That is, they have <kanji>axle</kanji>s.
hint: Imagine a car whose wheels don't turn on their <kanji>axis</kanji>. It has no <kanji>axle</kanji>s. Not a car that will work too well.

mnemonic: You walk up to a <radical>tree</radical> and put <radical>dynamite</radical> on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful <kanji>pattern</kanji> into the side of it as well as the ground around it.
hint: Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.

mnemonic: The <radical>tsunami</radical> that is <radical>white</radical> is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place <kanji>overnight</kanji>, without even asking!
hint: Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> breaks your <radical>bone</radical>s, not from hitting you, but from making the ground <kanji>slippery</kanji>. The water from the tsunami made all the sidewalks and stairs too slippery to walk on, but you tried anyway, slipped, and broke a couple bones.
hint: Imagine trying to get back up on the slippery ground. You've already broken a few bones, but you slip again, breaking a few more.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> crashes into the <radical>sun</radical> (breaking it in half) and creating a different <radical>wing</radical> of the tsunami all together. This wing crashes down and creates a <kanji>lagoon</kanji>.
hint: The lagoon is beautiful! The water is hot (from hitting the sun) but it isn't so bright that you'll get a sunburn.

mnemonic: You take a <radical>turkey</radical> and try to <radical>boil</radical> it but you <kanji>char</kanji> it instead. That's what happens when you throw meat into a pot on high with no water in there.
hint: You should know better than to try to boil something without water! Now what are you going to do with this raw, but charred turkey?!

mnemonic: This <radical>bamboo</radical> can be whittled into an <kanji>example</kanji> of anything. See, here's a <radical>car</radical>. Here's a <radical>snake</radical>. I can make so many examples just with bamboo.
hint: It's amazing how fast this guy can whittle!

mnemonic: Take this <radical>thread</radical> and look at this <radical>part</radical>. Now look at this part! Now look at this part. You don't know where to look! Haha, I have <kanji>distract</kanji>ed you!
hint: You don't know what part of the thread to look at. What a distraction.

mnemonic: <radical>Thread</radical> and <radical>vines</radical> alone are too weak to hold anything up. You need to <kanji>twist</kanji> them together to make them strong.
hint: Imagine twisting some threads and vines together. Feel them and twist the two tighter together.

mnemonic: If you take a <radical>thread</radical> and wrap up a bunch of it, so much it becomes a <radical>hill</radical> of thread, you're going to have a lot of thread. You can wrap some of that thread around other thread to create a much thicker thread. This thread is a <kanji>cable</kanji>.
hint: Imagine yourself twisting this hill of thread up to make thicker cables. They're strong!

mnemonic: You have a <radical>thread</radical> <radical>hill</radical>, but the hill is a bit weird looking (take a look at the hill radical in this kanji). It's not any normal hill, it's a weird lumpy hill that isn't quite right. That's because it is a thread hill of <kanji>netting</kanji>, and parts of the nets have caught things, like fish and cats, so there's weird abnormal lumps in them.
hint: You'll need to differentiate this from <ja>綱</ja>, which uses the same radicals (though <ja>綱</ja> has a real hill radical). Just remember that the weird "hill" has stuff caught in it because it is <kanji>netting</kanji>.

mnemonic: If the <radical>moon</radical> is <radical>dry</radical>, it's good for your <kanji>liver</kanji>! Haha, get it? Because there's no moonshine to ruin your liver. Don't drink, kids.
hint: Imagine holding an empty bottle up to the moon and seeing it's completely dry. You pat your belly above where your liver is and say, "I guess you're safe tonight, liver."

mnemonic: There are <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>hills</radical> in your front <kanji>lawn</kanji>. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.
hint: Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.

mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> find their <radical>death</radical> in a <radical>river</radical> out in the <kanji>wild</kanji>. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
hint: Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.

mnemonic: You keep your <radical>substitute</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> in a <kanji>sack</kanji>. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
hint: Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?

mnemonic: Who will <radical>say</radical> <radical>turkey</radical>? Who? <kanji>WHO</kanji>???
hint: Say "who" over and over again, demanding someone says "turkey," for some reason.

mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical>'s <radical>hat</radical>, not to mention the <radical>hair</radical> stuck to said hat, is incredibly <kanji>rare</kanji>. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.
hint: Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!

mnemonic: When a <radical>yakuza</radical> takes a <radical>knife</radical> to <radical>clothes</radical>, it will of course cause a <kanji>split</kanji> or <kanji>tear</kanji>.
hint: It doesn't matter if it's a yakuza member or not. Any knife will cause a split or tear in clothes.

mnemonic: <radical>Imperial</radical> <radical>clothes</radical> allow you to perform an ancient <kanji>attack</kanji> that cannot be repelled.
hint: IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.

mnemonic: This <radical>construction</radical> project made from <radical>shellfish</radical> will act as a <kanji>tribute</kanji> to the Crabigator.
hint: The Crabigator is a sea creature (maybe?), so making a tribute from shellfish makes some sense.

mnemonic: You have to <radical>run</radical>, put your <radical>ear</radical> on the <radical>stool</radical>, then run back. That's the <kanji>charm</kanji> of this game.
hint: Imagine yourself playing this game and basking in the charm of tapping your ear on the stool.

mnemonic: A <radical>foot</radical> on a <radical>giant</radical> is a pretty long <kanji>distance</kanji> for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large <kanji>distance</kanji>s very quickly.
hint: Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.

mnemonic: People had to ride their <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>plow</radical>s <radical>long ago</radical> to <kanji>enroll</kanji> in things. There were no cars yet, so they would hitch a cow to their bamboo plow, and dig their way to the government office or school to enroll.
hint: Picture the little hut that passed for school long ago. All of the bamboo plows are parked around it, as the people enroll themselves and their kids up for classes.

mnemonic: If the <radical>rain</radical> touches your <radical>foot</radical> and gives it a little rain <radical>kiss</radical>, you know that part of your foot is <kanji>expose</kanji>d to the elements. You can also see some <kanji>dew</kanji> forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!
hint: Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!

mnemonic: A <radical>cow</radical> in the <radical>winter</radical> doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the <kanji>pasture</kanji>. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.
hint: It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't want to leave the warm barn.

mnemonic: You take out a <radical>flag</radical>, lay a <radical>towel</radical> below it, and use your <radical>knife</radical> to carve the pattern through them both. Voila! This is exactly how old <kanji>printing</kanji> presses used to work.
hint: The old way of printing involved taking the pattern you want (the flag) pressing it against the place you want to print it (the towel) and then just slicing that sucker on there (with the knife).

mnemonic: A <radical>good</radical> <radical>moon</radical> is a <kanji>bright</kanji> moon. Not just in terms of light, but in mood as well. Like, gee wiz, what a bright, happy moon.
hint: Picture the good, good bright moon. Shining and shimmering and smiling down at us on Earth.

mnemonic: A small <radical>tsunami</radical> comes in the <radical>morning</radical> with the <radical>moon</radical>. That just means the ocean gets bigger when the moon's out, and that my friends is simply the <kanji>tide</kanji>.
hint: The moon does affect the tides a bit, so you can imagine the tsunami as the water getting bigger whenever the moon is out. That's just the tide.

mnemonic: The <radical>root</radical> of a <radical>stamp</radical> is to get an <kanji>instant</kanji> picture down. Back in the olden days, people had to make seals and draw out things by hand, so stamps came about so you can—BAM—just stamp it and have what you want in an instant.
hint: Lots of things have roots from wanting to have something in an instant. Just think about instant ramen. The root of that was to get ramen real, real fast. Similar to stamps, ya know?

mnemonic:
Look at the <radical>dirt</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> at <radical>dawn</radical> and you'll be able to see all the <kanji>hedge</kanji>s growing in the area really well. At any other time of day, hedges tend to blend into their surroundings. But at dawn, the shadows the sun makes really helps them stand out.

This hedge also works as a <kanji>fence</kanji>. It borders an area and you can't walk through it. A natural fence!
hint: Picture yourself leaning over a balcony at dawn, looking at all the hedges appear and their shadows stretch over the ground.

mnemonic: A <radical>drunkard</radical> goes down a <radical>slide</radical>, hits the <radical>ground</radical> and bumps into a <radical>woman</radical>. Who is that woman? It's none other than her <kanji>majesty</kanji>.
hint: The problem is that you don't want to run into her majesty. That's a grave offense. Feel the fear that you're going to get your head lopped off from running into her.

mnemonic: You need to make a <radical>measurement</radical> of an area so you take two clumps of <radical>dirt</radical> to <kanji>seal in</kanji> each side of your measuring tape, so it stays on the ground. This is the way people used to seal things back in the day, back when we didn't have fancy things like tape and glue.
hint: Picture sealing other things with dirt. Like the bricks in your wall. Or the hole in your floor. Dirt can seal in anything.

mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> stalk looks the <radical>same</radical> as a big ol' <kanji>cylinder</kanji>.
hint: Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.

mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is sticking in the <radical>ground</radical> on top of a <radical>mountain</radical>. It's sticking into the very <kanji>peak</kanji>. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
hint: Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's <kanji>peak</kanji>. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.

mnemonic: We put a <radical>flag</radical> to remember where we tried to use a <radical>jackhammer</radical> to <radical>measure</radical> your friend's <radical>heart</radical>. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of <kanji>consolation</kanji>?
hint: Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.

mnemonic: A <radical>badger</radical>, at the <radical>root</radical> of its <radical>heart</radical>, is a <kanji>courteous</kanji> creature.
hint: They may seem gruff and rude at first, but they'll still let you in their home in the middle of winter unannounced and offer you tea, a warm fire, and a place to sleep.

mnemonic: The <radical>loiter</radical>ing <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>king</radical> who hangs around during <radical>winter</radical> to provide an indication (this kanji uses the "indication" kanji as its top 2/3rds) of things to come now looks into your <radical>heart</radical>, and only sees bad things. So, he <kanji>chastise</kanji>s you about it.
hint: "What's in your heart is no good," he chastises you.

mnemonic: Below the <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>hand</radical>. The hand is just there to <kanji>chafe</kanji> against the trees.
hint: There's a hand just chafing against some trees. That's... interesting.

mnemonic: You hold the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> up with your <radical>fingers</radical> but it <kanji>grate</kanji>s on them. The roof is heavy, and you have to walk to keep up, so the roof is grating on them really, really badly.
hint: Have you ever been to a Japanese festival? There's always one of those portable shrines that are basically just roofs people hold up. That's what you're trying to hold with your fingers as the whole thing grates on them.

mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> in somebody's <radical>business</radical> by <kanji>slap</kanji>ping them! This method also works if someone is getting too involved in your business. Slaps are basically your way of doing business with your fingers.
hint: Imagine giving someone a good, hard slap in the face. You're all up in their business now.

mnemonic: The <radical>simultaneous</radical> radical and the <kanji>simultaneous</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

mnemonic: Take your <radical>spoon</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical> to be able to take a bite. It's <kanji>delicious</kanji>, you hear. That's the <kanji>point</kanji> of the spoon.
hint: Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn!

mnemonic: You've been ordered to <radical>spear</radical> this <radical>tree</radical> but you decide to be really <kanji>gentle</kanji> instead.
hint: Imagine gently poking the tree with your spear. You glance around nervously, hoping no one notices how easy on it you're being.

mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> hits a <radical>pirate</radical> they are going to <kanji>sink</kanji> no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.
hint: Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> can't resist the <radical>call</radical> of a <kanji>bog</kanji>. Whenever a tsunami is headed toward land, a bog will always call out to it, "Hey tsunami, don't you want to hit me with your water? Come this way~"
hint: Close your eyes and hear the bog's tempting call.

mnemonic: The sound of <radical>spring</radical> <radical>water</radical> always puts you at <kanji>peace</kanji>.
hint: Everything from winter is melting and trickling and thawing. All the dripping sounds fill you with a peace you can barely describe.

mnemonic: Hit by a <radical>tsunami</radical> the <radical>drunkard</radical> is propelled down a <radical>slide</radical> where he hits the <radical>ground</radical> which is covered in <radical>fire</radical>. He is immediately <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed.
hint: Even if he wasn't saved by the slide (to avoid the tsunami) he would be in trouble. Seems like the world just wanted to <kanji>destroy</kanji> this drunkard.

mnemonic: A (fresh water) <radical>tsunami</radical>. Some <radical>horns</radical>. The <radical>ground</radical>. A bunch of <radical>poop</radical>. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very <kanji>nourishing</kanji> soil.
hint: The stuff in horns is great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!

mnemonic: A <radical>fire</radical> <radical>door</radical> is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a <kanji>furnace</kanji>.
hint: Open the fire door and feel the heat of the <kanji>furnace</kanji>. Hot!

mnemonic: Two <radical>king</radical>s are here right <radical>now</radical>! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they'll do. Get out the <kanji>harp</kanji>, or the <kanji>zither</kanji>, or something.
hint: Imagine yourself playing a harp or a zither, even if you don't know how. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.

mnemonic: The <radical>measurement</radical> radical and the <kanji>measurement</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
hint: If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.

mnemonic: The <radical>dragon</radical> radical is the same as this kanji, which is <kanji>dragon</kanji>.
hint: Not to <kanji>dragon</kanji> with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!

mnemonic: There's a <radical>thread</radical> tying <radical>wolverine</radical> to a <radical>pig</radical>, balancing them over the <kanji>edge</kanji> of a cliff together.
hint: Picture wolverine and a pig hanging precariously over the edge. One move the wrong way and they'll both go toppling over.

mnemonic: A <radical>feather</radical> is on a <radical>rice paddy</radical>, and they are attached <radical>together</radical>. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one <kanji>wing</kanji> of your amazing aircraft.
hint: Imagine a <kanji>wing</kanji> that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.

mnemonic: The <radical>good luck</radical> radical and the <kanji>good luck</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

mnemonic: The radical <radical>blade</radical> and the kanji <kanji>blade</kanji> are exactly the same.
hint: Please, just know your radicals. Please!

mnemonic: If someone puts a <radical>blade</radical> to your <radical>heart</radical>, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation.
hint: Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!

mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> has an <radical>omen</radical> growing from it, one single <kanji>peach</kanji> that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
hint: Of course, this tree omen of a <kanji>peach</kanji> refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).

mnemonic: The <radical>spicy</radical> radical and <kanji>spicy</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
I <radical>say</radical>, which weighs more: a kilogram of <radical>scooter</radical>s or a kilogram of <radical>rice</radical>? This is a <kanji>riddle</kanji>!
hint: Think carefully and see if you can come up with the answer to my riddle before you read on.

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>temple</radical> isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a <kanji>samurai</kanji>, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
hint: You walk up to a temple and you're surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>big</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an <radical>umbrella</radical>. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is <kanji>I</kanji>. It is <kanji>me</kanji>.
hint: Imagine that this leader is you. Be rough about it, because <ja>俺</ja> is the "rougher" version of "I." You should only use it in casual situations or if you're a badass.

mnemonic: From my <radical>mouth</radical> I have told you <radical>seven</radical> times not to do that. Now I have to <kanji>scold</kanji> you.
hint: SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.

mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> loves her <radical>catapult</radical> for some good ol' fashioned <kanji>recreation</kanji>.
hint: You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.

mnemonic: The <radical>ladle</radical> radical and the <kanji>ladle</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Know your radicals, yo!

mnemonic: The <radical>slide</radical> to get off this <radical>jet</radical> is a beautiful, brilliant <kanji>vermilion</kanji> color.
hint: Vermilion is like an orange red, which is perfect for visibility purposes.

mnemonic: An <radical>axe</radical> is stuck into the <radical>ground</radical> on a <kanji>hill</kanji>.
hint: Imagine climbing up the hill. The sun is coming up behind the axe,  silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.

mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical> you cut off a <radical>tree</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> is a <kanji>pear</kanji>. I don't know if you've ever seen Asian pears, but they're pretty big and sturdy. You can't just pick them off of the tree, you need the help of a knife. That's why this is a pear, and not an apple or peach or something else.
hint: Imagine standing below a tree full of pears. You take your knife and carefully cut them all down, one by one.

mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> of <radical>business</radical>? Ha! That's <kanji>me</kanji>! That's <kanji>I</kanji>!
hint: This version of <kanji>I</kanji> is more boyish. It's a sort of young man/boy way of saying "I," though you'll hear women use it too sometimes (it's a teensy bit tomboyish though).

mnemonic: In the <radical>cage</radical> there are some <radical>legs</radical>. They are the legs attached to a <kanji>small animal</kanji>.
hint: You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.

mnemonic: You have <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>vines</radical>, so you <kanji>shout</kanji>! It's hard for you to talk normally, and even harder for people to understand you unless you shout.
hint: You were born with mouth vines (a rare condition where your mouth is always full of vines), so you've been shouting all your life. And yet people still can't hear you. It's very frustrating.

mnemonic: A <radical>gold</radical> <radical>pool</radical> is where you're going to go <kanji>fishing</kanji>. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
hint: Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great <kanji>fishing</kanji> spot this is.

mnemonic: Your <radical>long</radical> <radical>hair</radical> is your <radical>friend</radical>. It's your <kanji>hair</kanji> and you're so proud of it.
hint: Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.

mnemonic: The <radical>mountain</radical> <radical>wind</radical> coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a <kanji>storm</kanji>. Well, it is a storm, really.
hint: If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty <kanji>storm</kanji>.

mnemonic: A <radical>bamboo</radical> thing you put on your head to <radical>stand</radical> taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a <kanji>conical hat</kanji>.
hint: You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> goes through a little <radical>door</radical>, and plops down a <radical>big</radical> drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the <kanji>teardrop</kanji> coming down your eye.
hint: Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.

mnemonic: The radical <radical>can</radical> is the same as the kanji <kanji>can</kanji>. Usually when we talk about a can with this kanji we mean a <kanji>tin can</kanji>, though.
hint: Picture a tin can in your mind as clearly as you can.

mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> <radical>servant</radical> is the lower ranking <kanji>princess</kanji>. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
hint: Just imagine a princess saying "UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me." Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.

mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> with two <radical>moon</radical>s on either side, holding the tree up in a horizontal angle, is a <kanji>shelf</kanji>.
hint: So, your shelf is made up of a tree and two moons. Imagine this shelf and put things on it. The moons are kind of rolling around, making it hard to build your shelf.

mnemonic: The part of <radical>rice</radical> that <radical>stand</radical>s up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the <kanji>grains</kanji>.
hint: If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.

mnemonic: You put a <radical>stone</radical> into a <radical>wrap</radical> of some kind. This wrap happens to be a <kanji>cannon</kanji>, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
hint: This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!

mnemonic: <radical>Rain</radical> on a <radical>rice paddy</radical> means only one thing... <kanji>thunder</kanji>! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
hint: Imagine hearing the thunder as you run. It is getting closer.

mnemonic: A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>fang</radical> is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little <kanji>sprout</kanji>.
hint: Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).

mnemonic: When <radical>dirt</radical> and <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>suit</radical> one another, the flowers grow so tall that they make a <kanji>tower</kanji>! A flower tower made of flower power!
hint: Imagine walking in the woods and coming across a huge tower made of flowers. It goes so high you can hardly see the top.

mnemonic: When the <radical>tsunami</radical> struck, it hit your <radical>tent</radical> full of <radical>beans</radical>. When you lost your tent of beans, you had a moment of <kanji>lucidity</kanji>. You don't need so much stuff, you can live without it!
hint: Then you went back to being crazy. That moment of lucidity was only temporary, and you go back to stockpiling beans.

mnemonic: The <radical>spear</radical> radical and the <kanji>spear</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Spears are spears. It makes sense!

mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> <radical>table</radical> is a table that's made entirely of <kanji>skin</kanji>. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pores and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porous, skin.
hint: Touch it and feel the "moon table." You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.

mnemonic: The <radical>boat</radical> radical and the <kanji>boat</kanji> kanji are the same!
hint: Boats are boats, you know?

mnemonic: Something made of <radical>gold</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s in a <radical>village</radical>. It's a <kanji>bell</kanji>!  The village bell.
hint: Every village has a bell of its own, standing tall and proud and shiny in the middle for everyone to see and hear.

mnemonic: If there's a <radical>treasure chest</radical>, there's always a <kanji>villain</kanji> too. The villain is trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
hint: And the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain is SO important when it comes to treasure chests.

mnemonic: A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>demon</radical> is just a <kanji>lump</kanji>. Just like a dust bunny is just a clump of dust.
hint: Picture a lump of dirt. Is there a demon hiding under there? No. It's just a saying, ya nerd.

mnemonic: I <radical>protect</radical> my own <radical>animal</radical>s by going to <kanji>hunt</kanji> other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
hint: My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.

mnemonic: A <radical>spoon</radical> to measure a <radical>geoduck</radical> is a very <kanji>approximate</kanji> measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
hint: Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...

mnemonic: The <radical>cloud</radical> floating above a <radical>demon</radical> has its <kanji>soul</kanji> in it. If you can manage to get through to the demon, to make it see that it doesn't have to be evil, it might remember who it is and return to the <kanji>spirit</kanji> it once was.
hint: Right now, however, the demon is looming over you, and you can't see anything in the cloud above its head. It just looks mad, like it's gonna pummel you or eat you.

mnemonic: If you've been to the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>past</radical>, you had to get the special <radical>stamp</radical> on your <kanji>leg</kanji>.
hint: This leg stamp not only proved you went, but lets everyone around you know you've been to the moon before!

mnemonic: An <radical>alligator</radical> is <kanji>considerably</kanji> dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
hint: The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.

mnemonic: The <radical>well</radical> radical and the <kanji>well</kanji> kanji are the same.
hint: Make sure you remember that this is a well of water not a "well, actually."

mnemonic: From the <radical>mouth</radical> of your <radical>older brother</radical> comes... a <kanji>curse</kanji>!
hint: Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?

mnemonic: A <radical>woman</radical> who is a <radical>nurse</radical> should be called <kanji>miss</kanji>.
hint: Compare this to a man who is a nurse. You should probably call him mister. That's why you know a woman who is a nurse is "miss."

mnemonic: Looking up to the <radical>cliff</radical>, you see the <radical>tree</radical>s, and the <radical>sun</radical> shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole <kanji>calendar</kanji>.
hint: Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.

mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is being blocked by a <radical>rain</radical> <radical>cloud</radical>, making it <kanji>cloudy</kanji>.
hint: You look up at the sky, trying to find the sun, but it's so cloudy that you can't even find where the sun should be.

mnemonic: When your <radical>eye</radical> catches an <radical>omen</radical>, it's only natural that you will <kanji>stare</kanji> at it.
hint: You don't see omens that often, so of course you're going to stare. We'll imagine what the omen is in the reading mnemonic.

mnemonic: If you're showing me your "<radical>spirit</radical> <radical>fruit</radical>" then you are just <kanji>naked</kanji>. You're <kanji>nude</kanji>.
hint: You know what I mean by "spirit fruit" –– yep, it's out there and you're naked.

mnemonic: I'm putting all my <radical>shellfish</radical> on <radical>someone</radical>, hoping they'll win the race! This is a <kanji>gamble</kanji> and you're gambling.
hint: Remember, shellfish used to be used as money. So if you're betting shellfish on someone, you're just gambling. And you probably won't get any of those shellfish back.

mnemonic: I have <radical>sick</radical> in my <radical>skin</radical>. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably <kanji>exhausted</kanji>.
hint: Imagine yourself being really, really exhausted. Then look at your skin. It's all sickly looking.

mnemonic: There's a <radical>sock</radical> <radical>circle</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical> on your way to <kanji>cram school</kanji>. Every day after school you walk straight until you get to the sock circle, you run around it, and then head off in any direction. Somehow it always leads to cram school.
hint: Picture the sock circle in the dirt in your mind. Now look up and see cram school through the trees.

mnemonic: The <radical>toe</radical> is <radical>early</radical>. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the <kanji>table</kanji>.
hint: See all the toes lined up on the <kanji>table</kanji>. They are the ones who showed up early.

mnemonic: Below this <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>stone</radical>. Since it's the only stone here, you make sure to <kanji>polish</kanji> it.
hint: It's a single, perfectly round stone under this canopy of trees. It didn't start this way, but thanks to all the polishing you did, it has become nice and smooth.

mnemonic: When you leave <radical>grain</radical>s in your <radical>mouth</radical> for long enough, they'll turn into <radical>flowers</radical> of <kanji>bacteria</kanji>. These aren't the nice, pretty flowers you'd give your mom on Mother's Day. These are little bacteria flowers that are taking over your mouth. Maybe brush your teeth next time.
hint: Imagine how much bacteria would flower in your mouth if you just left grains in there for like, I dunno, a month. That's a lot of nasty bacteria!

mnemonic: This <radical>building</radical> <radical>now</radical> has a <radical>cloud</radical> over it, creating <kanji>shade</kanji>.
hint: This shade is really convenient right now, because it's been such a hot day. Ahh, shade is so nice and cool.

mnemonic: Coming down with the <radical>rain</radical> is <radical>two</radical> <radical>spikes</radical>. They go right through two <kanji>ghost</kanji>s.
hint: The ghosts are pinned to the ground by the spikes, unable to move.

mnemonic: After the <radical>tsunami</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> comes out again and shines on these <radical>spikes</radical>. They were super wet before, but you figure the sun probably dried them off. You lean down to touch them and nope, they's still <kanji>damp</kanji>.
hint: The sun did a little bit of work, so they aren't wet, but they aren't dry either. They're damp.

mnemonic: You feel like a <radical>stone</radical> (<radical>again</radical>!). When you feel like a stone, your body is feeling very <kanji>stiff</kanji>.
hint: Touch your stiff body. It feels like a stone.

mnemonic: The <radical>grain</radical>s you have stored in your <radical>house</radical> reflect on your <kanji>earnings</kanji>. If you earn a lot of money, you have more grains.
hint: Imagine looking at the grains in the houses of people who make vastly different earnings. The poor artist has only a few sacks of grain. The rich samurai has an extra house just for holding his grain. That's how you know he has much higher earnings than the artist.

mnemonic: The <radical>woman</radical> who makes your <radical>house</radical> a home is your <kanji>bride</kanji>.
hint: She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.

mnemonic: <radical>Tsunami</radical> vs <radical>lifeguard</radical>. Who will win? After the water drains away, we find the lifeguard in the <kanji>gutter</kanji>.
hint: To be fair, it's pretty obvious who would win. Nobody knows what that lifeguard was thinking.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> in the shape of a <radical>dragon</radical> flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a <kanji>waterfall</kanji>.
hint: Can you see why a tsunami dragon (especially the Asian skinny snake-like kind) could be a waterfall? Try to imagine it.

mnemonic: The <radical>animal</radical> <radical>king</radical>? He's just this guy who lives in the forest and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a <kanji>lunatic</kanji>, though.
hint: While we're speaking of animals, he's absolutely bat sh*t crazy.

mnemonic: A <radical>sheep</radical> with <radical>feathers</radical> (and presumably wings, too) is able to <kanji>fly</kanji>.
hint: Imagine the sheep with feathers taking off and flying around. It's an odd sight, but makes sense, kind of.

mnemonic: You use <radical>black</radical> <radical>dirt</radical> to make <kanji>black ink</kanji>. That's what you use to write in black!
hint: Make sure the dirt you're using to make black ink is really, really black. Like the kind you find around volcanoes or something.

mnemonic: There are <radical>nine</radical> <radical>bird</radical>s and one of them is a <kanji>dove</kanji> and another is a <kanji>pigeon</kanji>. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders.
hint: Look at these nine birds strutting down the street like they own the place. The dove and pigeon are out in front because they are the most important. Hear them chirping and fluttering their feathers about.

mnemonic: Some <radical>grains</radical> get stuck in his <radical>cleat</radical>, and <radical>Wolverine</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> grows <kanji>calm</kanji>. Wolverine had been screaming and yelling and stomping around, but when the grains entered his cleat he realized where he was. He was finally able to calm down.
hint: He's calm now because he stomped right into a farmer's field (thus the rice) and if he didn't calm down he'd probably ruin it.

mnemonic: Make <radical>barracks</radical> out of <radical>gold</radical> and they will get <kanji>dull</kanji> quickly. Gold is soft, it's okay for jewelry and delicate things that aren't used much, but barracks for soldiers? Those are used constantly, and they get worn out easily. What was once shiny gold will go dull in days.
hint: Picture a huge barracks made of dull, almost brown, gold. Maybe you should have picked a better material.

mnemonic: Below the <radical>canopy</radical> of <radical>tree</radical>s is a <radical>demon</radical>. This demon is a <kanji>devil</kanji>.
hint: You thought the devil hangs out in hell, but he actually hangs out under this canopy of trees.

mnemonic: You need to bring <radical>charcoal</radical> under this <radical>roof</radical> to heat the <kanji>dormitory</kanji>. You live in this dormitory with a bunch of other kids, and you all have to take turns bringing in the charcoal from outside to heat it.
hint: Imagine looking at a dormitory chore wheel and seeing it's your turn to carry in the charcoal this week. Bleh!

mnemonic: I found <radical>part</radical> of a <radical>plate</radical> at the <kanji>lantern festival</kanji>, and put it on a <kanji>tray</kanji> to keep it safe. There is a legendary plate broken into three parts. One part of the plate I found was at the lantern festival. The lantern festival was pretty cool, but I’m really glad I found the part of that plate I was looking for.
hint: Imagine holding a tray in your hands with this part of the plate on it, as the light from the lanterns glitters off it and dances around, illuminating the background. It’s enchanting.

mnemonic: There’s a <radical>tree</radical> in the <radical>east</radical> that looks like a <kanji>pillar</kanji>. The tree is tall and straight and does not have any leaves or branches. The tree is basically a big wooden pillar that just happens to be alive still.
hint: Look at this big tree pillar over in the east. You always know where east is because of it.

mnemonic: I have <radical>five</radical> things in my <radical>mouth</radical> and <kanji>I</kanji> need them all for <kanji>me</kanji>. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
hint: What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.

mnemonic: You use your <radical>car</radical> and an <radical>axe</radical> to <kanji>slice</kanji> down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood.
hint: Imagine driving your car, waving your axe out the window and slicing this guy down. Hear his scream ring in your ears as you slice, slice, SLICE.

mnemonic: On the <radical>roof</radical> is your <radical>heart</radical>. OR! In a <radical>net</radical> in the <radical>street</radical>. Which would you <kanji>rather</kanji>?
hint: Would you rather have your heart up on the roof, close to falling but out of the way of people. Or would you rather have your heart in a net, which people can't steal from, but is in the way of cars.

mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> is very <radical>odd</radical>, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a <kanji>chair</kanji>!
hint: Imagine this odd tree <kanji>chair</kanji> being the most comfortable chair you've ever sat on. It's shaped perfectly for you, and the moss makes it soft. Wow, what a chair.

mnemonic: You need to <radical>stop</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> from going down a <radical>slide</radical> with a <radical>jackhammer</radical> to ask him how many <kanji>years old</kanji> he is. He's doing a lot of dangerous things right now, and they all have age limits.
hint: Depending how many years old he is, this guy could be violating like three different laws right now.

mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> causes the <radical>capital</radical> to become very <kanji>cool</kanji>. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool.
hint: Imagine being in the capital. The tsunami hits and now you are all wet. You are also very cool because the water is not warm. You are cool and wet. How sad.

mnemonic: An <radical>animal</radical> that <radical>kick</radical>s <radical>dirt</radical> into people's <radical>mouth</radical>s is a <kanji>monkey</kanji>. Monkeys are naughty little things. You should be happy it was just dirt it kicked into your mouth, and not something worse.
hint: Imagine looking at a monkey at the zoo. Aww, it's so cute. But then it turns around and kicks some dirt right into your aww-ing mouth. Yuck! Why monkey, why?!

mnemonic: Inside your <radical>eye</radical> <radical>stand</radical>s a tiny <radical>village</radical> that makes up your <kanji>pupil</kanji>. That's the black part of your eye!
hint: Oh, did you think your pupil was a hole? No, no, you misunderstand. That's where the village stands. It's full of little people who whisper to your brain what you should see.

mnemonic: You take some <radical>gold</radical> and cover your <radical>yoga</radical> <radical>brush</radical> in it, turning it into a <kanji>key</kanji>. You shove the brush you normally use for yoga into the lock to your car and pour the gold over it. Now it's the right shape to be a key!
hint: You lost your old key, you see. But you're a go with the flow type of person, thanks to all the yoga, so you make a new one!

mnemonic: You get <radical>rain</radical> <radical>orders</radical>. Your orders are to make sure there is <kanji>zero</kanji> <kanji>spill</kanji>.
hint: Despite it raining, your orders are to make sure none (zero!) of the rain spills anywhere. Figure out what you need to do to make sure you follow these rain orders successfully. Zero spill, alright?

mnemonic: A <radical>crab</radical> moves a <radical>stone</radical> because he is playing the game <kanji>Go</kanji>. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good.
hint: Look at this crab placing stones on the Go board. Hear them click and clack as the crab places them with expert precision.

mnemonic: Someone with a <radical>top hat</radical> comes and tells you that your <radical>grain</radical>s are going to be taxed from now on. Top hat man says there is a <kanji>tariff</kanji> that's been enacted on grains. Rice? Triple the price. Wheat? Quadruple.
hint: People in top hats like to put tariffs on lots of things. Especially things you need, like grains you eat to stay alive. You have no choice but to pay.

mnemonic: <radical>Poop</radical> <radical>Poop</radical> <radical>Mountain</radical> is covered in poop because it is such a <kanji>secluded</kanji> place.
hint: A secluded place has no toilets, so you just poop right on the mountain.

mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>wrap</radical>s around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of <kanji>bubbles</kanji>. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, a whole lot of bubbles are created.
hint: Picture the bubbles bursting out of the wrapped up tsunami as it crashes down. The air that the tsunami sucked in while it was wrapping up come out as bubbles big and small.

mnemonic: When you get <radical>sick</radical> you always eat a <radical>hot pepper</radical>. It's a <kanji>habit</kanji> you've picked up and you can't seem to shake it. One sniffle, one cough, and before you know it, you're eating a hot pepper or two.
hint: Imagine if you had a habit of eating hot peppers whenever you thought you might be getting sick. To be fair, it flushes out your sinuses and tastes good, so it's not the worst habit you could have.

mnemonic: You want to turn your <radical>gold</radical> <radical>comb</radical> into a <radical>weapon</radical>, so you throw it into the <kanji>forge</kanji>.
hint: Once the gold comb has melted down in the forge, you can forge it into whatever weapon you want.

mnemonic: The <radical>gold</radical> from the <radical>east</radical> needs <kanji>tempering</kanji> before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it’s entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you’d do in a forge.
hint: Imagine tempering this gold from the east. You’re heat treating the gold when you’re tempering it, so feel the heat from the fire on your face and arms.

meaning: Head of Plant, Ear Of Plant
mnemonic: The part of the <radical>grain</radical> people <radical>favor</radical> the most is the <kanji>head of the plant</kanji>. You don't eat the stems and leaves of rice or wheat plants, right? You eat the head where the grains are.
hint: Imagine yourself walking through a field of rice plants. Now look very closely at the head of the plant in front of you. See the rice bunched up there? That's the good stuff.

mnemonic: You <radical>stand</radical> your <radical>towel</radical> up so everyone can see it. This announces that you are the <kanji>sovereign</kanji> ruler of this bathroom.
hint: Whenever someone walks into your bathroom, you start screaming that you are the sovereign ruler of this toilet, this sink, this toothbrush, and all that touch these tiles.

mnemonic: Your <radical>eye</radical> gets kicked with a <radical>cleat</radical> that came careening toward your <radical>forehead</radical> when it popped off someone doing a <radical>dance</radical>, and you <kanji>blink</kanji>.
hint: Well, of course you blink, you can't control that. And when a cleat come hurtling toward your eye it blinks automatically.

mnemonic: If you pick certain <radical>rice</radical> or <radical>flowers</radical> you'll be put in <radical>prison</radical>. The most famous of these is the <kanji>chrysanthemum</kanji>. Chrysanthemums are super important in Japan because they're the symbol of the imperial family. They're even on the cover of Japanese passports. If you get caught picking a chrysanthemum, you're going to prison.
hint: Chrysanthemums are really important to the Japanese people. Please don't ever pick them (or rice, because that's stealing food, someone planted that)!

mnemonic: "<radical>Say</radical> '<radical>big</radical>,' <radical>ground</radical> <radical>beggar</radical>! Have <kanji>pride</kanji>!"
hint: You are trying to tell a beggar on the ground to say they are big, because you want to make the beggar feel a little pride. "Have pride in your job as a beggar!" you tell them.

mnemonic: You're standing under a <radical>canopy</radical> when you see something strange sticking out of the <radical>dirt</radical>. You pull it, but it won't budge. You pull harder and harder until the dirt starts rumbling and a giant <kanji>manor</kanji> starts rising out of the ground with you on top!
hint: Picture yourself on top of this manor that rose out of the ground. The canopy is still above you and it seems to be attached to the roof.

mnemonic: If you see a <radical>building</radical> wearing a giant <radical>top hat</radical>, beware! This building is a fake and it's trying to <kanji>thwart</kanji> all of the plans the people in other buildings have.
hint: Picture the building, with it's tall top hat, inching closer to other buildings when no one is looking. It's planning to thwart everything!

mnemonic: Your village wants to take the <radical>village</radical> <radical>dog</radical> and <radical>boil</radical> it, and you can think of no other response than <kanji>SHUT UP</kanji>!
hint: The entire village is shouting and yelling and pointing at the poor dog. They're boiling a giant boiling pot of water, and you can't even hear yourself think anymore. Shut up, shut up, shut up!

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of your sad <radical>life</radical> aims a <radical>kick</radical> at the <kanji>sack</kanji> you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it’s not something you want to have kicked.
hint: See this leader’s kick coming at your sack. Hear the leader yelling as he aims his kick at your sack. Hiyahhh! Also keep in mind that the life radical is missing the little drop/slide thing on the side. It’s missing that because your life is lousy and sad.

mnemonic: The <radical>white</radical> <radical>thread</radical> in your <radical>towel</radical> comes from <kanji>cotton</kanji>. We use cotton to make lots of things, like clothes and bedsheets. But white towels are always made from soft, fluffy cotton.
hint: Imagine shoving your face into a nice, clean, white cotton towel. Mmm, so fresh.

mnemonic: With the <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> you command a <radical>tree</radical> to become a <kanji>shelf</kanji>. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth.
hint: Imagine using your mouth to turn a tree into a shelf. Yell at this tree and keep yelling at it until you see it become a shelf.

mnemonic: Take this <radical>stone</radical> and throw it at <radical>nine</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es to <kanji>smash</kanji> them! It's like old-fashioned bowling, but instead of rolling this stone to knock down the crosses, you want to completely smash them to bits!
hint: Picture the nine crosses in front of you, lined up in a triangle. Now take your rock, hold it above your head, and SMASH it down on them as hard as you can!!

mnemonic: Your <radical>rice</radical> <radical>fortune</radical> is <kanji>sticky</kanji>. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice.
hint: Look at this sticky rice fortune of yours. Run your hands through it and feel the sticky rice between your fingers. Hear the sticky sucking sounds and you stir the sticky rice about.

mnemonic: Sitting safely under your <radical>canopy</radical> you take <radical>rice</radical> and <radical>dirt</radical>, mix it up, and create unique <kanji>cosmetics</kanji> for your face.
hint: Imagine mixing dirt and rice together to make some cosmetics that best fit your skin tone and type. No one will see you doing it under this canopy too, so the secret formula you come up with will be safe.

mnemonic: A <radical>crab</radical> will try to hide what it <radical>lack</radical>s with <kanji>deceit</kanji>. Lying, stealing, faking things—no type of deceit is too much for a crab.
hint: Covering things up with deceit is pretty much the worst thing you can do, so don't be like this crab.

mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> the <radical>key</radical> to telling a <kanji>lie</kanji> is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key.
hint: Imagine an actual key going from you to another person. This key is the lie. You gotta believe in the lie for it to reach the other person and unlock their understanding. Visualize this visual lie.

mnemonic: It's <radical>rain</radical>ing on your <radical>spear</radical> that has <radical>winter</radical> <radical>power</radical>. When the warm rain hits your cold, winter spear, it creates <kanji>fog</kanji>.
hint: When warm water touches a cold spear, fog billows out and covers everything.

mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> that is <radical>stamp</radical>ed with one pattern, then <radical>stamp</radical>ed with another pattern, over and over, is the <kanji>willow</kanji> tree.
hint: A willow tree is a tree that looks like it's on repeat over and over again. It also looks nice on a stamp. Note that the first stamp is kind of an ugly looking backwards stamp, and the second stamp is the normal stamp radical.

mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> and <radical>Wolverine</radical> take a <radical>slide</radical> to <kanji>Italy</kanji>. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!
hint: Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~

mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of a <radical>narwhal</radical> <radical>construction</radical> crew needs all the <kanji>help</kanji> he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.
hint: Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.

mnemonic: This <radical>shrimp</radical> is the exact length of a <kanji>shaku</kanji>, or <kanji>Japanese foot</kanji>. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.
hint: Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.

mnemonic: With a <radical>lid</radical>, you hit yourself in the <radical>mouth</radical> and then <radical>kick</radical> it like a <kanji>pathetic</kanji> loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.
hint: Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.

mnemonic: A <radical>landslide</radical> came out of your <radical>mouth</radical> and created your <kanji>lips</kanji>. Before the landslide, you just had a wide open mouth hole.
hint: Picture your mouth as an open hole. Now a landslide of something (words? food? something worse?) comes pouring out, and when it's done you have lips. You flap them open and closed to test them out.

mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical> there are <radical>flag</radical>s and <radical>horns</radical> lined up with a <radical>lantern</radical> attached to them, making a <kanji>fence</kanji>. It's a little weird looking, but these things are definitely supposed to fence something in.
hint: Can you see the fence made of horns and flags through the light of the lantern?

mnemonic: A <radical>building</radical> falls into the <radical>dirt</radical> when a <radical>pig</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> <kanji>crash</kanji>es into it. The building literally crashes to the ground when the horned pig attacks it.
hint: Picture a pig with horns crashing into a building and both of them crashing into the dirt. Uh oh, is the pig dead?

mnemonic: With a <radical>woman</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical>, you have a <kanji>likeness</kanji> to me.
hint: Imagine someone's putting a woman's mouth over your mouth, looking at you, and commenting on your likeness. All it took was this woman's mouth.

mnemonic: A <radical>wave</radical> crashes into a <radical>woman</radical>, transforming her into an <kanji>old woman</kanji>! The wave washes away all of the woman’s makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.
hint: Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.

mnemonic: There is a <radical>mountain</radical> on top of a bunch of <radical>dirt</radical> with a steep <radical>cliff</radical>. This is a bit redundant, but the mountain and the dirt just make the <kanji>cliff</kanji> even bigger and steeper and scarier.
hint: Imagine a cliff. Now add two big helpings of dirt and a mountain to the top. It's still a cliff, it's just more cliff than before.

mnemonic: You take a <radical>towel</radical> and wrap it around your head to keep the <radical>sun</radical> out of your <radical>eye</radical>s. You've invented... the <kanji>hat</kanji>!
hint: A hat is just a piece of cloth or a towel you get to stay on your head. Extra points if it protect your eyes from the sun.

mnemonic: That <radical>penguin</radical> over there seems to have a <radical>towel</radical> stuffed with <kanji>cash</kanji>.
hint: The towel the cash is in even has a big $ on it like the ones they have at the bank. You follow the penguin into a back alley.

mnemonic: A <radical>soul</radical> will only inhabit a <radical>root</radical> if it's holding a <kanji>grudge</kanji>. Have you ever seen a nice, haunted tree? No! They're always angry and trying to get someone back for something.
hint: Don't die with a grudge, or your soul might end up angry and trapped in some roots.

mnemonic: The <radical>soul</radical> <radical>mask</radical> helps you to see the deepest part of anyone's soul. You look around and in all the people you only see <kanji>hate</kanji>.
hint: You're supposed to see all the emotions, so why do you only see hate inside everyone?

mnemonic: You keep your <radical>tongue</radical> to your <radical>self</radical> to give your <radical>heart</radical> a <kanji>rest</kanji>. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self rest time.
hint: It's important to let yourself rest every now and then, you know.

mnemonic: After passing through a <radical>door</radical>, you use a <radical>feather</radical> to put the finishing touches on a <kanji>folding fan</kanji>. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.
hint: Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.

mnemonic: The <radical>door</radical> a <radical>criminal</radical> will get into is the <kanji>front door</kanji>. Now hold on, you may be thinking, wouldn't they go for the back door? No! 99% of home invasions happen when you leave your own front door unlocked!
hint: You better check the locks on your front door right now, because odds are you left it open and didn't even notice. It's the perfect door for a criminal to get access to your home.

mnemonic: You have <radical>fingers</radical> in the <radical>thousand</radical>s and while looking up at the <radical>sun</radical> you decide you want to <kanji>insert</kanji> them in there.
hint: Hold your thousand+ fingers up to the sun and imagine inserting them into the sun's super-hot ... s-sun lava. (That's what it is, right? Yeah, let's go with that.)

mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> moves your <radical>mouth</radical> with his <radical>hand</radical> to <kanji>manipulate</kanji> it. He sticks his hand into your mouth. With the Viking's hand in your mouth, he can make you look like you’re saying anything he wants.
hint: Imagine the Viking having his hand in your mouth. Taste his salty flesh on your tongue. Imagine him manipulating your mouth and your jaw and making it look like you are saying all sorts of funny things.
